TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to a typically humble statement of the Prime Minister in March 1990 in the following terms:

QUESTION.PARA: Before 1985 Australia was run by the bureaucracy. This Government runs the whole outfit. I run economic policy—and the Government.

In view of the Prime Minister's boast that he runs the Treasury, why should the Australian people believe that the Treasury's analysis of the coalition's Fightback package is anything more than Treasury simply doing what he tells it to do?

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I came in here, I read some comments on this issue by former Senator John Stone. Former Senator Stone, who was once head of Treasury of course, commented in that article that the Treasury provided impartial advice to government.
—It was then.
—`Then and now', he said.
—How would he know about it now?

—Senator Macdonald interjects, `How would he know about it now?'. He would know as much as the honourable senator—probably a lot more. I am talking about what ex-Senator Stone had to say. Senator Stone went on to say that it was the function of Treasury not only to provide advice to government but also to provide analysis in respect of documents and views which were in the public domain and in the political debate.

PARA.TAB: I thought Opposition senators would have known that because these documents were largely obtained as a result of use of FOI by the Opposition. Looking at the situation, the fact is that the work done on Fightback was commissioned long before Mr Keating became Prime Minister and when he was not, in fact, a member of the Government. So I think Senator Hill has really missed the point of this. I agree with the views expressed by the former head of Treasury and a former senator in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the intense interest shown by various sections of the Australian community, will the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade advise the Senate of the Government's intentions with regard to recognition of the Yugoslavian Republic of Macedonia?

—The Australian Government is acutely conscious of the sensitivities that are involved in relation to the question of the recognition of what is presently known as the Yugoslavian Republic of Macedonia. From the point of view of the people living in this and other parts of the region, and their friends and relatives abroad, we understand and sympathise with their struggle to fulfil their legitimate aspirations for democracy and independence.

PARA.TAB: We are concerned about the continuing human suffering which exists in the former region, and we are totally supportive of the efforts within the European Community and the United Nations to bring about a lasting peace.

From the point of view of Greece, and the Greek community in Australia, the question of the recognition of the Yugoslavian republic known as Macedonia does create a number of problems which do not exist in relation to other present or former Yugoslav republics. The Greek concerns extend to the use of the name `Macedonia', with all its historical and cultural associations; the question of Skopje's commitment to accepting the sovereignty and inviolability of the whole of present day Greece; and also the question of the protection of minorities, in particular the Albanians, who boycotted the 1991 independence referendum.

The Australian Government is well aware of the strength of feeling which exists on all these issues. We could hardly be otherwise, I guess, given the scale of the rallies and protests around Australia in recent days and weeks. We are also aware of the divided opinion on the issues in question in Europe and will certainly have close regard to the actions taken by the majority of the countries in that region before we make any decision of our own.

Australia will not proceed to recognition until the following basic, outstanding questions are resolved: the name issue—the use of the word `Macedonia'—being settled in a way which does not cause further tension with Greece; Greece's concern about possible territorial claims or aspirations being fully met; and the international community's concern about the protection of minorities being fully satisfied.

Intense efforts are now under way in Europe to achieve a mutually acceptable outcome between Athens and Skopje on all the relevant issues, and it is important that the Australian Government does not by its actions take any steps that would prejudice that process. We do not want to state any Australian position which assumes that a consensual solution is impossible.

Might I just say that the position I have stated is no different in its essentials from that spelt out on behalf of the Opposition, at least by its official spokesmen—first, Senator Hill on 22 February, and then by Dr Hewson on 28 February. It is a matter of regret, I have to say, that some more strident and unqualified statements by some Opposition Party members have had the effect of turning the issue in some people's minds into a political football. It should not be anything of the kind.

Finally, Australian policy will continue to be guided above all by our assessment of what will most contribute to the harmonisation of relations between the former Yugoslav republics, and between them and their neighbouring states. We have no wish to see the recognition issue determined in any way which serves only to create new regional tensions in a region which has already been undergoing such rapid change.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Button representing the Treasurer. Has the Treasury carried out a distributional analysis of the Government's economic statement using the same methodology it has applied to its analysis of the coalition's Fightback package? If so, will the Government provide the full results of that analysis to the Parliament? If it has not conducted such an analysis, will the Minister explain the reasons for not doing so?
—If Senator Short reads the documents accompanying the statement made by the Prime Minister last week, he will find a considerable degree of analysis in terms of the economy in them.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short asked me about the distributional impact. I do not know whether any work has been done at this stage on the distributional impact of that package. I just want to make the point that, in terms of lower income earners, there has been a considerable period of targeting lower income earners—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they have had it too good for too long.
—Yes, they have had it too good for too long, said Senator Alston by way of interjection. Lower income earners have had it too good for too long; that is what Senator Alston said.
—Order!

—One thing is certain about the Government's position as distinct from that of the Opposition with its consumption tax package; it does not try to use the same sum of money to compensate lower income earners and at the same time deal with bracket creep in respect of the tax rates paid by lower income earners, which is what the consumption tax package does.

PARA.TAB: I have already referred to targeting of lower income groups in the tax scales by this Government, which takes account of bracket creep, I think, to 1995. But the second thing in the package is the improvement in the family allowance and the family allowance supplement, which was very much targeted to lower income earners. In terms of any analysis by the Treasury, if that is done, I am sure it would be published at the appropriate time.

TALK.START.PARA: —When is that?
—Well, the appropriate time is when we decide or when those opposite seek it through FOI. Let me say that that would, I believe, be done.

PARA.TAB: As distinct from the consumption tax package of the Opposition, the statement made by the Prime Minister last Wednesday does not purport to be a blueprint for every conceivable issue with which this country might be confronted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, those opposite need a blueprint for every conceivable issue because it enables them to go `Bah-bah, Fightback good, everything else bad' all the time and that gives them a feeling of warmth which they have not otherwise had.
—You have got it wrong 15 times.
—In respect of Senator Macdonald's repeated interjections, let me say that I have already commented on that issue, but he was having a discussion with somebody else at the time and did not notice.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the Minister does not seem to know the answer to my question, which I find extraordinary, would he not agree that it would be equally extraordinary for the Government not to subject its own package to the same conceptual analysis to which it has subjected the coalition's package? May I also ask, in the light of his comments about bracket creep, whether the Government's economic statement makes any provision at all to give back to taxpayers the additional revenue gained through inflation pushing taxpayers into higher marginal income tax brackets? In other words, does the Government's package make any provision at all for pay back of bracket creep?

—There are three parts to the supplementary question. First, Senator Short said that I did not know the answer as to what analysis would be done by Treasury, and he found that surprising. I would not find it surprising. Life is a wheelbarrow full of surprises. The fact that Senator Short, hotted up by this most unfortunate analysis of the consumption tax package from his point of view, the blood rushing to his head, leaps in here today and says, `Ah, we are doing an analysis too', suggesting that I do not know the answer, does not surprise me at all and it should not surprise Senator Short. I am not a know-all like those opposite who blah-blah about the consumption tax package all the time. It purports to be a solution to everything and it is not, as they will see in the next few months.

PARA.TAB: As for the question of fair treatment of conceptual analyses, that depends on my obtaining an answer to the first part of the question. As for whether this Government as distinct from any other government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the economic statement look after bracket creep?

—Senator Short has asked his question. I understand his anxiety to change his question now because the first part was stupid. He now wants to change. The question was whether this puts back anything lost by bracket creep over the years to the taxpayer, as distinct from every other government in the history of Australia.
—Does it give it back or not?

—No, it does not, nor does the consumption tax package. The consumption tax package does a two card trick with respect to lower income earners—it compensates them for the disability of a consumption tax and also compensates them for bracket creep with the same amount of money. That is something which cannot be done, even by this highly inventive Opposition.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the recent reports of fighting in Cambodia, including the wounding of a senior Australian officer with the UN peace keeping force, can the Minister advise what further progress has been made on the implementation of the Cambodia settlement, including the establishment of an Australian mission in Phnom Penh and increased aid to Cambodia?

—I am pleased to report to the Senate that on 28 February the United Nations Security Council approved the overall plan for the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia, or UNTAC. A number of countries, including ourselves, have expressed concern previously about the delays in the deployment of UNTAC putting the Cambodia settlement under some pressure. With the Security Council's approval of that plan, the main part of the implementation of the settlement can now begin.

PARA.TAB: We are expecting the UN Special Representative, Mr Akashi, to be in Phnom Penh by mid-March. The Australian General, John Sanderson, who is expected to command the UNTAC military forces, will also hopefully be arriving in Phnom Penh at that time to head up an operation including personnel from some 30 UN member states. The UN Secretary-General, Boutros Ghali, has noted that the plan is directed towards an April 1993 target date for the holding of democratic elections. He will be in Cambodia in April this year.

The reality is that the UNTAC plan, in its final form—although it is like extracting teeth to get the Opposition to admit this—contains many basic ideas proposed and developed by Australia. I think we can be very pleased with the progress that has been made in its implementation.

As far as Australia's contribution to the operating plan is concerned, we have offered to contribute around 500 personnel, plus or minus, to the peace-keeping operation. That includes the 65 ADF communications personnel who are already serving with the advance mission. We expect to receive very shortly a formal UN request for the participation of Australian personnel. As soon as the details are clarified, we will be making a detailed statement about this to Parliament.

In addition, we will be contributing our assessed financial contribution of 1.51 per cent of the total UNTAC budget. We will also be responding to appeals for voluntary contributions to other UN programs for repatriation and rehabilitation. We have already delivered $1m to the UN High Commissioner for Refugees for repatriation.

Just what the size of the financial impost will be really depends on what the overall total cost of the operation is. On the present planning parameters, it could be as high as US$1.9 billion. The hope by a number of countries, including ourselves, is that it may be possible to implement these planning numbers on a phased basis, which will mean that it may not necessarily be the case that the full number of personnel that have been identified as costing that much will, in fact, be required.

As to the other parts of the question, the Australian mission in Phnom Penh has been established with the first resident Ambassador, Mr Holloway, presenting his credentials on 1 December last. That mission currently has a staff of 10 Australia-based officers, including officers from the Department of Defence, DILGEA and AIDAB. That is soon to increase to 14. It performs the whole range of functions that one would expect.

In terms of bilateral aid, restrictions on our bilateral aid were lifted in 1991 following a decision to recognise the SNC. An AIDAB planning mission visited Cambodia in January-February and the Government will shortly decide what funds can be made available for direct aid this financial year. This financial year, indirect aid from Australia to Cambodia, along with flood relief and refugee assistance, has totalled almost $14m.

Finally, as to international development assistance, the settlement provides for the establishment of ICORC, the International Committee for the Reconstruction of Cambodia, to coordinate international development assistance. We see a need to move quickly to establish this because of the large flow of international aid, the need for its coordination and the need to coordinate, in particular, rehabilitation projects to be carried out by UNTAC. The major international financial institutions are now planning for major assistance programs to Cambodia. We understand that the Asian Development Bank envisages a program of concessional loans and technical assistance with special emphasis on the rehabilitation of transport and communications infrastructure. The World Bank plans to send a mission to Cambodia in April.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Much of the Opposition's Fightback package is based on a model of the Australian economy built by Dr Murphy—the so-called Murphy model. Much of the Government's criticism of Fightback has also been based on the application of the Murphy and other economic models. Is it a fact that these economic models assume that, no matter how government spends its money, the long term net effect on the productivity of the Australian economy is zero?

—I do not think that assumption is correct in either case. I have looked at the consumption tax document. It makes a few assumptions about productivity, some of which are in the tables. So I do not think the issue has been ignored by the coalition, and it certainly has not been ignored by us. We see significant productivity growth coming out of the recession. We see a much better capacity to sustain that productivity growth than we have had in the past as a result of structural changes made in the Australian economy.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister obviously misunderstood the question. I am not surprised at the Minister being ignorant because I find that neither the Government nor the Opposition look behind their models. Does the Minister agree that the Australian economy would be productively different if, on the one hand, the Government spent its resources on building an efficient rail system or on improving the quality of education or, on the other hand, on support for the gambling industry? If the Minister does agree, then does he not think that the present debate over which package is best, based as it is on economic models, which I remind the Minister assume a zero effect—
—Order! Senator Coulter, this is a supplementary question, not a speech.
—Does the Minister not think that the whole debate, which has been based on these models, should be shifted towards an emphasis on the human needs in Australian society?

—Mr President, that is said to be a supplementary question. It is the first supplementary question I have ever had which bears no resemblance at all to the original question. Let me say that I understand it better now. The question is whether in the longer term one achieves a more productive economy as a whole by directing resources into particular areas, which in Senator Coulter's terminology is defined as the productivity of the rail system on the one hand as against the productivity of a casino on the other. Of course the answer to that question is yes. If we made those assumptions there would be differences in the very long term modelling of an economy such as Australia's revealed by choosing one or other of those two scenarios.

PARA.TAB: I have to remind the honourable senator that the productivity discussion we have had here really turns on productivity in industry over the next few years without substantial changes being made in the emphasis on investment and consumption expenditure in Australia.

I see the point of the question. I do not think the models take into account the sorts of things Senator Coulter has now mentioned, and I think that in the longer term it would be desirable if they did.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations whether his attention has been drawn to reports that Australia is undergoing `one of the worst bouts of strikes in more than a decade'. Is it not a fact that, thanks to the accord, the recent level of strikes has been roughly 60 per cent below that which the Government inherited from the Liberals? Is the only departure from this national trend to be found in New South Wales, where there was a general strike last October against the Greiner Government's industrial relations legislation? Finally, I ask the Minister to advise the Senate why the transition to workplace level wage bargaining seems to be more confrontationist in New South Wales than in any other State of Australia.

—I have seen the newspaper reports. The most bizarre one was in yesterday's Australian Financial Review in which some weird interpretative skills were used to interpret the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures. I prefer to go to the source—the ABS figures themselves. Those figures just published for the month of October show that under Labor's cooperative approach to industrial management the dispute figures go down and follow the trend downwards under us. Under the Liberal Party's conflict approach to industrial matters, the dispute figures go up and show a worsening trend.

PARA.TAB: It is true that disputes have fallen by 60 per cent under the Labor Government compared with that of the previous Government—the Liberal-National Party Fraser Government. In New South Wales we are in danger of pushing our record into a worse situation by the unfortunate performance in handling industrial matters by the conservative Greiner Liberal Government. It is showing that Labor States reduce disputes and Liberal States—in this case, New South Wales—increase them.

Let me demonstrate that point. The New South Wales labour force consists of approximately two million workers. For October, those two million workers lost 549,800 working days. The rest of Australia, where the work force is four million, lost 13,700 working days through industrial disputes. New South Wales, with half as many workers as the rest of Australia, had 40 times more industrial disputes than the rest of Australia or an incidence of 260 per thousand compared with 3.4 in the rest of Australia.

The reason is that in New South Wales there was a protest stoppage about anti-union legislation and anti-industrial relations legislation by the Greiner Government. That stoppage accounted for 94.6 per cent of all lost time in Australia for the month of October. If we take New South Wales as a whole, it accounted for 97.6 per cent of all lost time in Australia due to industrial disputes.

The conclusions that can be made from this data are that without the one day stoppage the Australian figures would have continued downwards; they would have been at 205 per thousand compared with 217 per thousand for the same month in the calendar year 1990. The trend under Labor would have continued to go down except for that one incident. Without this strike, the figure for New South Wales would have—

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody believes PK and they do not believe you either.

—Senator Macdonald ought to understand that if we take New South Wales out of a sample the figure for the rest of Australia continues down, but if we leave New South Wales in the sample the figure for Australia goes up. It also confirms that the Fraser style confrontation in New South Wales—the anti-union cast of that Government to destruct the union movement to drive wages down for ordinary working people—does lead to industrial disputes. In Labor States, in which they have been quietly going about creating harmony in the workplace, the dispute figures are low. This is in microcosm what we could expect in macrocosm if a Hewson government came to power, given that industrial relations and a consumption tax are cited as the key features of the Fightback policy. It shows why Australian businessmen increasingly say to Mr Howard, as he goes around the traps, `Don't come and talk to us; your policy creates more problems than it's worth. We don't want to speak to you'.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to last night's Four Corners program in which the ABC acquired at least part of a copy of the Treasury analysis of the Fightback! document. Will the Minister inform the Senate why the document was selectively leaked to the ABC prior to its presentation as a ministerial statement to the Parliament today; or will the Minister guarantee that the FOI material provided to that program did not come from the Government, its Ministers or its staff?
—I have no idea how the material arrived at the Four Corners program. However, I am quite convinced that it did not come from the Treasury.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister is asserting that the document used by the ABC was not leaked, it must therefore have been taken illegally. —Well, I am sorry, Senator, it does not, because I did not say that the document was not leaked. Senator Bishop phrased her supplementary question in terms of, `If it was not leaked, as you say, therefore it must have been stolen'. Well, I do not make that assumption at all.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Yesterday during Question Time the Minister informed the Senate that he had spoken to the chief executives of each of the four Australian car manufacturers. He told the Senate that they had assured him that they would pass on the benefits of the cut in wholesale sales tax announced in last week's economic statement to consumers in full. Is the Minister aware of media reports in this morning's press which indicate that new car prices are going up, and can he explain to the Senate why this is occurring?
—Why did you lie?

—Senator Alston, ready as usual with a witticism, says `Why did you lie?' His suggestion is not implicit or apparent from the question. I was telephoned this morning by the chief executive of General Motors in Australia, Mr Bill Hamel, who had also seen the reports in the newspapers. He assured me that the reports were untrue in so far as they related to the price of Holden cars, particularly the Commodore.I understand that General Motors has advertisements in the same newspapers saying that the price of Holdens will go down by twice the amount of the savings in the sales tax announced last week. Mr Hamel backs this up by saying that the Holden dealers will match the tax savings dollar for dollar on the company's entire range of passenger cars. I should point out, however, that the advertisement says that this offer runs until 31 March.

PARA.TAB: There are some price rises in the offing, particularly for imported cars, as a result of exchange rate variations. The depreciation of the dollar against the yen has increased the price of some imported cars and will also have some effect on the price of cars produced in Australia which contain a high level of imported components.

However, I just make a general point about the motor vehicle industry. Australian manufacturers express their concern about the increasing penetration of imports into the new car market in Australia. That is happening, I think, largely because of a move to smaller cars not produced in this country, which may or may not be of a permanent nature. I make the point to car manufacturers in Australia that price rises on their cars are an excellent way of assisting importers to take a bigger share of the Australian market.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they going to do—sit there and go broke? You really don't understand business.
—What did you do in your shadow portfolio today?
—Order!

—I cannot participate in this debate. The effects of the devaluation of the dollar are, of course, felt harder by the importers than the domestic manufacturers. I believe that Australian producers should be making the most of this benefit, not squandering it. It is very important to car manufacturers that they build market share, but also that they build the size of the market overall—and price, as Australia comes out of the recession, is one way of building market share and building the size of the market in this country. After all, we have a fairly aged car population here. Car manufacturers can contribute to a reduction in the age of the Australian motor vehicle fleet by passing on the price reductions which follow from the reduction in sales tax and by attending to the question of growing the market as well as market share. So the manufacturers should match the price restraint shown by their components suppliers—and which they expect from their components suppliers—and by their workers. Last year, for the first time in several years, manufacturers increased their prices faster than inflation, and this is not something that they can continue doing in the long run if they wish to survive and flourish.
—What happened to their profits last year?

—It varied from company to company. Holden made profits; Nissan, of course, made losses—16 years in a row. Various companies had different profit results. But all of them, of course, were slightly or considerably down on the previous year as a result of the recession.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Why did the Treasury assume an inflation rate of 3.5 per cent in assessing the Government's One Nation package, yet assume an inflation rate of 7 per cent in assessing the coalition's Fightback package?

—It is not a matter of assuming; it is a matter of calculating, and any consumption tax package will increase inflation. There is no doubt about that; everybody agrees with that. Even the consumption tax document itself agrees that a consumption tax will increase the inflation rate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —People are accusing each other of lying here. I want to drop a pearl of truth in front of Senator Reid and I should not be interrupted by that. In the excitement of these last two days, Dr Hewson and his merry men have got a bit rattled about all these figures. For example, we had Mr Reith on Four Corners last night talking about the Treasury estimate of 3.9 per cent. Senator Reid says 3.5 per cent. The actual figure was 4.6 per cent. This compares with the coalition estimate of 4.7 per cent without the—

—No, I have not got it wrong. Senator Walters should go back and have a look. That is the figure without the health care changes. So the estimates are a little rubbery in terms of what the Opposition is saying.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. Quite clearly, once again the Minister is trying to speak about the Opposition's package.
—What is the point of order?

—The point of order is that, in accordance with the President's ruling, when answering a question about his portfolio he is entitled to speak only about that part pertinent thereto. The Minister cannot even get it right when he tries to talk about something outside his portfolio. Mr President, would you please ask him to stick to his area of influence, otherwise to remain seated.
—I was asked a question about the Opposition's package, as well as the One Nation statement. Perhaps Senator Bishop—
—Order! The Leader of the Government was asked a question about the Government's policies and the Opposition's policy. Therefore, he is in order.

—Perhaps if Senator Bishop, instead of preparing her interrupting speech for television through a point of order, had bothered to listen to the question her colleague Senator Reid asked, she would have understood that point and never made her speech.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In the light of recurring reports that the Indonesian security forces in East Timor have been continuing a campaign of intimidation against the Timorese, including very recent allegations of the detention of up to 500 young people in Taibesse, and given that two of the marchers have been charged with subversion, which carries the death penalty, what steps has the Government taken to ascertain the specific charges laid against all East Timorese currently in detention in Jakarta and Dili in relation to the Santa Cruz massacre? What steps are being taken to ensure that the East Timorese are treated humanely and are given fair trials according to international norms? Finally, will Australian diplomatic staff be observing these trials?

—The most recent assessment provided by our own Embassy as to conditions in East Timor was in mid-February. That assessment, which was based on a series of regular and recent visits to the province and on discussions with a range of people who had also recently visited there, was that daily life in Dili had returned to close to normal, although a great deal of tension and uncertainty remained. There were few confirmed accounts of human rights abuses since the beginning of the year, and no evidence, at that stage at least, to substantiate allegations of a recent deterioration in the human rights situation.

PARA.TAB: Since that assessment was provided, the new military commander in East Timor has been reported as saying that three people have been arrested for allegedly holding meetings in connection with the forthcoming visit of the vessel Lusitania Expresso. In light of Senator Bourne's comments, I will instruct the Embassy to provide an updated assessment of the situation in East Timor, including with regard to these allegations of intimidation and, in particular, the suggestion of the detention of 500 young people in Taibesse.

As to her three specific questions, officials from our Embassy in Jakarta have been in regular contact with a whole range of government and non-government sources in order to ascertain the charges laid against the East Timorese in relation to the Santa Cruz killings affair. Our latest information is that, of the 384 East Timorese originally detained in Dili, Bali and Jakarta for their alleged activities in connection with the 12 November affair and for related activities, 345 have already been released and another 26 are shortly to be released.

Of the remaining 13, four are to face subversion charges and nine are to be charged with lesser offences. As to what those lesser offences are, we know that three detainees in Jakarta are to be charged with violations of the criminal code—namely, publicly expressing enmity or hatred or insulting the Government. With regard to those charged with subversion, although it is the case, as has been reported, that the maximum penalty is death, in practice this sentence is rarely imposed. I for one would find it absolutely extraordinary were the imposition of that sentence to be the case here.

As to the second part of the question, I have raised it with my counterpart, Foreign Minister Alatas, and our Embassy is also continuing to make clear in representations to the Indonesian Government our belief that no-one should be detained or otherwise penalised for non-violent political activities, that those detained should be treated humanely, and that those brought to court should be given proper legal representation and fair trials.

Finally, as to the question of observation of trials, our Embassy in Jakarta will be monitoring the course of the trials of the East Timorese detainees to the best of its ability through a combination of media reports—because the trials are expected to be open—contacts with Indonesian NGOs and the detainees' legal counsel and also through appropriate Indonesian legal authorities. Against this background, and given our resource constraints, I do not believe that there is a need for Australian officials themselves to attend the trials.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Did the Minister recently lead a tripartite mission to Japan which sought, amongst other things, to explain the extent of structural economic changes which had taken place in Australia? Can he advise how the mission was received by the Japanese business community?

—Between 25 January and 1 February I led a tripartite mission comprising, among others, Bryan Noakes, the Director-General of the Confederation of Australian Industry, and Martin Ferguson, the President of the ACTU, to Japan. We had over 30 meetings with senior Japanese business leaders, business organisations, government and unions. It was by all accounts a very successful exercise on behalf of Australia in Japan.

PARA.TAB: The two objectives of our mission were to explain the fundamental nature of changes in industrial relations in this country, to emphasise to the Japanese that we are moving away from the old conservative Fraser era period of confrontation to a cooperative approach in industrial relations, and to learn from the Japanese about labour relations in that country, in particular how productivity can better be promoted. During those meetings Bryan Noakes paid this Government the compliment of saying that there have been more changes, more improvements, in industrial relations in the last six years than there have been in the last 40 years. Martin Ferguson, on behalf of the ACTU, indicated that the union movement in this country is supportive of the cooperative approach of the Australian Government, recognises the need to build long term good relations with employers, and is undergoing significant rationalisation to cut down demarcation disputes.

The reports of the mission have been that it was a resounding success, the points having been made that there is a climate change in Australia in industrial relations—disputes are down 60 per cent from the Fraser years—that there is a growing recognition that in Australian workplaces a revolution is going on in improving work practices and generating higher productivity, and that this Government creates the right framework for that to grow and develop and to push a productivity surge through the economy when the recovery is more fully under way.

It might also be reported that the Japanese media were complimentary about what we said while we were there. The Nihon Keizai Shimbun, the leading Japanese daily financial newspaper, described our approach to putting our case to the Japanese as being `smarter than the Americans'; stated that we were demonstrating that we were achieving significant change; and added that that was a very positive consideration.

We placed a great deal of importance on this mission. It puts aside the old stereotype that Australia is industrial dispute prone. It creates a situation in which the Japanese can see the restructuring that has occurred and recognise the investment opportunities that are here.

TALK.START.PARA: —The frequency band plans grant important discretions which could affect people's livelihoods, with no clear distinction of who is to exercise this power, no criteria to guide and limit the discretion, and no indication of review rights. They also include what may be a legislative power involving compulsion in otherwise helpful notes in the body of the instrument.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Capital Territory electoral regulations provide good quality safeguards for persons who fail to vote in elections and who subsequently elect to pay an administrative penalty rather than go to court. However, the regulations do not provide for persons affected to be notified of these safeguards. Mr President, as usual I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief statement of the concerns of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The document read as follows—
VHF HIGH BAND FREQUENCY BAND PLAN
STATUTORY RULES 1991 NO. 354
VHF MID BAND FREQUENCY BAND PLAN
STATUTORY RULES 1991 NO.355

Both these instruments are unusual examples of Statutory Rules which are not regulations. They were made under the parent Radiocommunications Act 1983, which provides that the Minister may prepare frequency band plans, consistent with the spectrum plan in the Act, providing for the purposes, the areas and the times during which the band may be used. The present instruments provide for the expansion of existing services and the introduction of new kinds of services. Both Plans were accompanied by extensive Explanatory Statements. They also included general and specific Notes in the body of each instrument.

However, the Committee still has concerns about the instruments. These concerns relate to appropriate safeguards for users of the radio spectrum who are affected by the Plans. Both Plans provide for wide exemptions from their apparently mandatory requirements with inadequate criteria for the exercise of this power, the instruments themselves merely providing that an exemption may be granted where arrangements are more efficient, with no further criteria. There is a Note which lists further criteria, but there is no advice whether these criteria have a legislative basis (for example, they may have been informally extracted from the parent or another Act) or are simply advisory guidelines drawn up by the Department. Another provision includes the expression, "unless the contrary intention appears", with no advice as to who decides whether this is the case. Another appears to authorise complete exemption from an important part of the Plan without any immediate indication, at least on its face, of who is to exercise this discretion.

A Note advises that another discretion exists with the Secretary, or any officer of the Department authorised by the Secretary, with no indication of whether this power is legislative or administrative. There is no apparent provision in either of the instruments for review of these discretions.

Other Notes advise that each Regional Office of the Department will develop and manage the detailed program for conversion of services in their region. Such conversion "will generally require modification or replacement of existing equipment" and "individual users will be required by the relevant Regional Office to convert their service earlier than the relevant State conversion date". The Notes then list what are stated to be measures to minimise the impact of the cost and disruption for users. It is unusual for such power, which appears to include compulsion, to be given to public servants, possibly without direct legislative authority. In any event, it is normal for safeguards for users to be included directly in statutory rules, rather than in Notes.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (ELECTORAL) (MODIFICATIONS OF THE COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL ACT 1918) REGULATIONS, STATUTORY RULES 1991 NO.397
These Regulations modify many aspects of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 in its application to the Australian Capital Territory.

One set of modifications provide that a person who does not reply to a "please explain" notice in respect of an alleged failure to vote in an election, or who replies and whose explanation for not voting is not accepted, may opt either to pay $20 to the Electoral Commissioner or to appear before the Magistrate's Court, where the maximum penalty is $50 plus costs.

The Regulations provide good quality safeguards for those people who are satisfied to be dealt with by administrative procedures rather than appear before a court. If such people pay the $20, then they discharge all liability in respect of the offence, they may not be charged in any other proceedings and, of special significance, they are not regarded as having been convicted of an offence. These are very important safeguards which should receive the widest possible publicity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) relating to the Opposition's consumption tax package and to move a motion to take note of the statement and a related document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: On 26 November 1991, the Leader of the Opposition, on behalf of the Opposition Parties, tabled in this House a document titled Fightback! which contained, among other things, the Opposition's taxation and expenditure proposals for the next Federal elections.

The monument of the package is the proposed imposition of a new tax of 15% on the purchase and consumption—by every Australian—of nearly all goods and services. This would raise, on the Opposition's figuring, some $27.2 billion.

For many years, it has been recognised as being in the public interest for the policies of the "alternative government" of the day to be costed and analysed in terms of their economic and social impacts, in much the same way as policy proposals of the Government of the day are subjected to rigorous official analysis and testing.

In accordance with this long established practice—observed by successive Governments, of all political persuasions—the Opposition's consumption tax proposals have been subjected to the official scrutiny of the Departments of the Treasury and Finance.

On 9 December 1991, my colleague the Minister for Finance publicly released the Department of Finance costings of the Opposition's expenditure proposals as spelled out in its so-called Fightback package. A week later, on 16 December, the Minister made public the details of an analysis by the Treasury and the Australian Taxation Office of the revenue side of the package.

The Treasury has also undertaken a distributional analysis of the Opposition's package which, as far as it is technically possible to do so, traces the complex and clouded money flows in the package and identifies the net financial impact on Australian households. This analysis was not publicly released ahead of the rising of the Parliament for the summer recess.

On 18 December 1991, the honourable Member for Flinders made an application under the Freedom of Information Act 1982 (FOI) for access to documents provided between 19 November and 17 December 1991 to the then Treasurer and his predecessor by the Department of the Treasury and the Treasurer's Office which relate to the Opposition's consumption tax package.

Upon the change in Ministerial arrangements in late December and my assuming the responsibilities for the Treasury portfolio, I reviewed the documents which are the subject of the FOI application and I determined that as the documents are of general public interest, they be tabled in this House within the first five sitting days of the next sitting, as provided for under section 21 (1) (d) of the FOI Act. The documents I will be tabling today include three prepared within the Treasurer's Office itself—namely documents 1, 2 and 16.
2. FISCAL HOLE

Honourable senators will recall that, taken together, the costings prepared by the Departments of Finance and Treasury and the Taxation Office demonstrated that the Opposition's figuring on its package is fundamentally flawed. The proposed expenditure cuts are massively overstated to the order of $2.7 billion and revenue is understated to the order of $1.1 billion, giving a total funding shortfall in the package of nearly $4 billion. On the best information available to those official agencies that would have primary responsibility for implementation of the package, it does not add up: it has a $4 billion hole. To that extent, the package is simply not capable of implementation unless it were to be fundamentally re-cast and re-worked.
How can the Opposition have got it so wrong?
To put this in context, the Opposition's package would be underfunded by the amount necessary to pay, for example, for three of the key elements of the "compensation" package:

PARA.TAB: the shortfall means that the Opposition could not fund the 8% increase in social security and veteran's pensions and the 6% increase in all other social security, education and training allowances. These are intended to compensate for the inflationary effect of the consumption tax (they have been costed by the Department of Finance at $2,374 million in year 3)
and the Opposition would not have the funds to meet its promised increases in Family Allowances ($1.036 billion)

in addition, the $565 million re-insurance pool subsidy to reduce the rising costs of health insurance premiums, as result of elderly and chronically ill people taking out private insurance, could not be funded.

SPEECH.PARA: From these objective costings of the Opposition's package, it is quite clear that, if it were ever to win Government, the Opposition's promises to compensate Australians for the introduction of its consumption tax could not be met. Perhaps this is what the Opposition Leader meant when he declared, in launching the package, that "My concept of compassion isn't to compensate them for what I fail to deliver . . . .".
Alternatively, the Opposition could cover its funding gap with a substantially higher consumption tax—say, at 17.5% rather than the 15%—with no compensation for the additional impost.

The Opposition claim that it will not do this. The Leader of the Opposition went so far as to solemnly declare that he would resign before countenancing such an increase. But if the rate isn't increased, what are the Opposition Leader's options? The promised compensation would have to be slashed: pensioners and families would miss out, but they would still have to pay a new 15% tax on every single item of food consumed, clothing bought and anything else they purchased.

The $4 billion fiscal hole is itself enough to sink Fightback as a credible economic statement. But Treasury's distributional analysis, which will be among the documents to be tabled today, exposes its shallowness as a political manifesto. Fightback is like the cities built for Catherine of Russia: all facade and no substance.
3. DISTRIBUTIONAL ANALYSIS

Let us, for the purposes of this exercise, suspend reality and go to that model world inhabited by the Opposition, where "two plus two" might add up to five or maybe only three, depending on the needs of the situation. It's a world where white is just a lighter shade of grey and where black, after all, is just a darker shade of grey. Let us, for the purposes of this exercise, put aside the $4 billion hole in the Opposition's calculations.
To go to the very heart of the point, for two months the Leader of the Opposition has been travelling the country declaring that under the Opposition's tax package "everyone will be a winner".

The Opposition Leader's declaration is based on chapter 17 of his consumption tax plan, which purports to quantify "the impact of the Coalition's reform (sic) package on the net financial position of Australian households.
The Opposition has made three key assertions concerning the redistributional effects of its package. These are:

PARA.TAB: that all groups in the community show increases in average disposable income after allowing for the effects of the consumption tax
that there is a bias in the package in favour of families with children
and that the distribution of net benefits is skewed in favour of lower income groups.

SPEECH.PARA: Treasury's analysis, however, has demonstrated that each of these claims is untrue. The consumption tax appears to be little more than a disguise for a redistribution of income from lower and middle income earners to high income earners.

Detailed examination of the consumption tax package shows—contrary to the assertions of the Opposition—that there are, in fact, very few winners. Indeed, so far as it is possible to follow the consumption tax money trail and using the Opposition's methodology—and I will deal with the methodology of the Opposition's figuring in a moment—that trail leads to an outcome where over 70% of households of full-time wage and salary earners and about 60% of self-employed and farmer households would be worse off under the Opposition's proposed arrangements (see Attachment 1).

In particular, the Treasury analysis shows that wage and salary earner and self-employed and farm households on incomes of $90,000 a year and above would be better off by between $15 and $105 a week—that is, by up to $5,460 a year better off.

By contrast, married full-time wage and salary earners with non-working spouses and children, and family incomes up to $57,000 a year, would be worse off by up to $8 a week—that is, up to $400 a year worse off.
Similarly, self-employed and farm households with incomes up to $61,000 a year would be anything up to $12 a week worse off.
Attachment 2 shows the full distributional results of the Treasury analysis before road user charges and the funding shortfall are allocated.

Further, the Treasury analysis shows that, under the Opposition's preferred Scenario C, on the tax measures alone—that is, not factoring in any other changes—all people paying tax on incomes below $40,000 a year would not be adequately compensated both for bracket creep and for the price effect of the Opposition's package. That is, the Opposition's own proposed tax scales would not compensate low and middle income earners for its new food and clothing tax (see Attachments 3 and 4).

For example, a taxpayer on an income of $30,000 a year would receive a tax cut of 6.8% under the Opposition's announced plan but, after taking account of bracket creep and the CPI impact of the consumption tax, taxpayers on this income would still suffer a decline in real disposable income of some 2%.
Thus, while taxpayers on an income of $30,000 a year would be $9.20 a week worse off, people on $100,000 a year would be $73.20 a week better off.

In other words, taxpayers on $30,000 would receive a tax cut which would be only about three-quarters of that necessary to compensate for the introduction of the consumption tax. But people on $100,000 would get a tax cut which is almost double that which would be adequate to compensate them for the reduction in their purchasing power.
This is the Opposition's notion of fairness—an Opposition which last and this week was in mock mourning over the plight of low income earners.

The major beneficiaries of the Opposition's package would be the top 10% of each type of wage and salary earner household and self-employed and farm households. Meanwhile Treasury's analysis clearly shows that the vast majority of full-time wage and salary earner households would see their real incomes fall.
4. METHODOLOGICAL SHORTCOMINGS OF OPPOSITION ANALYSIS
The Treasury's distributional results are very different to those contained in chapter 17 of the Opposition's consumption tax plan.
How could the Opposition have got it so wrong?

It is not just that the Opposition made some mistakes—and make some fundamental mistakes they certainly did. Regrettably, all the evidence suggests that the Opposition's analysis, which shows "everyone to be a winner", is clearly deceptive.
The reasons for the difference between Treasury's distributional analysis and that of the Opposition and its advisers are very straightforward.
To begin with, Opposition calculations do not include all of the elements of the package that the Opposition is actually proposing to implement.
On one side of the ledger, the Opposition has included in its distributional analysis anything at all that could be characterised as compensating for the consumption tax.

It has reduced the price increases flowing from the consumption tax with each and every price decrease which it has calculated will flow from its promised abolition of the wholesale sale tax, payroll tax and fuel excise. And it has included as a benefit to households each and every "gain" which it has calculated to flow from personal income tax cuts and tax rebates, consumption tax credits, health tax credits and increases in government transfer payments.
But, on the other side of the ledger, the Opposition appears to have left out those parts of the package that most hurt low to middle income households.
For example, the Opposition appears to have excluded from its distributional analysis the impact of such significant funding elements of its own package as:

PARA.TAB: expenditure savings of approximately of $6.5 billion (based on its own costings), including changes in the eligibility for some transfer payments
increases in a range of other taxes including tobacco excise, company tax, the Medicare levy surcharge on high income earners and the dependent spouse rebate income test
changes to health care arrangements, such as removal of bulk-billing for most Australians
bracket creep, which is estimated to contribute about $3 billion to the funding of the Opposition package
and some non-funding elements such as the Opposition's superannuation and savings policies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasury analysis has imputed a number of the expenditure cuts but has not attempted to impute to households all the elements excluded from the Opposition analysis. Accordingly, the Treasury analysis not only understates the number of households that are worse off, but also understates the extent to which households are actually worse off.
But, in contrast to the Opposition's analysis, the Treasury's work has taken into account a number of the Opposition's funding proposals. These include:

PARA.TAB: introduction of the proposed family income test for the dependent spouse rebate
lowering the income test threshold for Family Allowance
removing AUSTUDY where present eligibility is less than $30 a week
the health care measures such as removal of bulk-billing for most Australians
tightening of the income and assets tests for pensions, Family Allowance, Family Allowance Supplement, AUSTUDY, and the junior Job Search Allowance
a new parental income and assets tests for 18-20 year old Job Search Allowance recipients living at home
removal of the sole parent pension where the child is aged 12 or over (assuming that the sole parent transfers to JSA)
and bracket creep.

SPEECH.PARA: The point, of course, is not to do with the merits or otherwise of any or all of these proposals.
The point is that, while the Opposition claims that it is being frank and honest with the community, it omits from its calculations issues which are capable of analysis under its methodology.
But that is not the end of the Opposition's creative accountancy methods.
5. HOUSEHOLD EXPENDITURE SURVEY DATA
The basis of both the Treasury distributional analysis and that of the Opposition is the 1988-89 Household Expenditure Survey (HES).

Table 17.4 of the Opposition document presents estimates of the "percentage increase in real disposable incomes" as a result of its package. As the Opposition concludes, the change in real disposable income is the appropriate measure of the adequacy of compensation [page 301].

Changes in real disposable income are calculated for 140 different household types or cells. These 140 cells consist of a 14-way split based on household characteristics combined with a 10-way split based on income for each household type. This 10-way split divides households of any given type (e.g. self-employed and farmers) into 10 equal groups, called deciles, based on income. Thus decile 1 represents the lowest 10% of income earners for that household group, decile 2 represents the second lowest and so on up to the tenth decile.
The Opposition has represented Table 17.4 as an illustration of the full effect of its package on different households.
In fact it falls well short of that description.
In the first place, as I have already pointed out, the Opposition has excluded significant elements of its package from its analysis.
In the second place, the Opposition has treated all cells as equally valid representations of the impact of the consumption tax package on households of that type and income range.
This treatment of the HES data is wrong. It is nothing more than a statistical nonsense.

The HES is based on a sample survey. As the data are divided into smaller and smaller sub-sets, the accuracy of any derived estimates declines rapidly. Some cells used in the Opposition analysis contain as few as 7 households and are clearly useless as a guide to the impact of the package.

In fact, it is questionable practice to apply any statistical analysis to a cell containing fewer than 30 households—they are statistically insignificant. But some 50 of the 140 cells in the Opposition analysis fall into this category. That is, over one-third of the cells in the Opposition's analysis are statistically insignificant and should be ignored as they cannot provide any meaningful guide to the effect of the Opposition's package.

These cells have been reported in Treasury's own analysis simply for the sake of comparison and to provide consistency with the Opposition's tables. But the Treasury has been at pains to put distance between it and the statistical methods of the Opposition. I note that among the documents to be tabled today—document 3 in fact—is a minute dated 19 December 1991 which, in commenting on a draft press release, insisted that the words "on the basis of the Opposition's methodology" be inserted because:

PARA.TAB: ". . . .we would not want it to appear that Treasury was endorsing this type of analysis as providing realistic estimates of likely distributional outcomes".

SPEECH.PARA: So much for the Opposition and what it claims to be a "professional" analysis.
6. BRACKET CREEP
But that's still not the end of the illusion. The Opposition also uses taxpayers' own funds—the result of bracket creep—to fund compensation.

Tax bracket creep describes the increase in the tax burden caused when the tax scale is not adjusted for the effects of inflation. Accordingly, unless the tax scale is adjusted, higher nominal wage levels push taxpayers into higher average tax rates.

The Opposition plans to use all of the available results of bracket creep—about $3 billion—to help fund its promised tax cuts. This is presented as compensation for the consumption tax. Of course, the return of bracket creep can in no way compensate for the inflationary impact of the Opposition's consumption tax package. True compensation requires that taxpayers have all the bracket creep returned before they receive any additional tax cuts as compensation for the consumption tax.

In other words, the Opposition has been very vocal about its fist full of dollars but it hasn't mentioned at all that it will have a hand in every taxpayer's pocket to pay for it. Quite simply, the Opposition is proposing to take $3 billion out of the pockets of Australian taxpayers in order to give it back to them in the guise of "compensation" for the introduction of their consumption tax. This is a very crude pea and thimble trick indeed.

Attachment 3 compares the Opposition's proposed tax cuts with what would actually be required to compensate for the CPI effect of the consumption tax package and bracket creep. On this measure alone—that is, not allowing for other tax and expenditure changes or a higher CPI effect—it can be seen that all people paying tax on incomes below $40,000 a year would not be adequately compensated by the Opposition's proposed tax scales for the price effect of the consumption tax package. This means that the overwhelming majority of Australian taxpayers will not be adequately compensated.

Taking this $3 billion from bracket creep together with the $4 billion fiscal hole, it is clear that of the compensation which the Opposition is offering, $7 billion of that, is simply not available to the Opposition for its purposes.
How could the Opposition get it so wrong?
7. INFLATION EFFECTS
Inflation outcomes are, of course, central to the calculation of the "compensation" element of the consumption tax package and to its broad macro-economic impact.

The Opposition calculated the CPI effect of its consumption tax to be 4.7 per cent. Treasury's calculation, on the same basis, resulted in a 3.9 per cent effect. The inclusion of Opposition health policy changes increased the estimated net CPI effect to 4.6 per cent.

However, to this must be added a further 0.3% to account for the proposed reintroduction of the recently removed Medicare co-payment and the reduction in the wholesale sales tax on passenger motor vehicles, bringing the calculated effect to 4.9%.
There is also the problematic area of road user charges which the Opposition has committed itself to introducing but for which the Opposition has steadfastly refused to provide any details.

Currently, road users, through fuel excises and registration fees, contribute to government revenues more than is required to meet road expenditures. The Government, in consultation with the States, has been developing proposals for road user charges that seek to redistribute the charging burden according to road use. They do not aim to increase the amount of revenue raised from road users.

Treasury has modelled the effects of an illustrative road user charge based on vehicle registration fees designed to ensure that aggregate road expenditure is paid for by users. This modelling implies an average increase in registration fees of more than 160 per cent for light vehicles and over 200 per cent for heavy vehicles.

Accordingly, if the Opposition proceeded—as it has indicated it would—with registration based road user charges, on the reasonable assumption that these would be designed to recoup costs, these charges would add over one percentage point to the CPI impact of the Opposition's proposals. The total CPI effect of the Opposition's package would thus be 5.6 per cent—before the impact of the removal of the Medicare co-payment and wholesale sales tax changes on cars.
What does this mean in terms of the Opposition's proposed compensation package?

The short answer is that, combined with the other elements in the Opposition's package, the increases in registration fees would leave more than 80 per cent of full-time wage and salary, self employed and farm households worse off. The majority of full-time wage and salary earner households would see real disposable income fall by between $5 and $35 per week, while the majority of self employed and farm households would be between $4 and $22 per week worse off (see Attachment 5).

It is important to understand, however, that it is not just the total CPI increase that is relevant: the distribution of price increases across the basket of goods and services that people purchase illustrates starkly why this is truly a tax on food and clothing, as illustrated so graphically by my predecessor on 19 December 1991.
The estimated price effects (see Attachment 6) of the Opposition package on food products generally will be 8.9% overall (or 9.57% with the effect of road user charges):

PARA.TAB: dairy products will increase by 9.6% (10.4% with road user charges)
cereal products will increase by 9.2% (9.9% with road charges)
fresh fruit and vegetables will increase by 10.1% (11% with road charges).

SPEECH.PARA: But one supposes the Opposition will proudly point to the fact that, while the price increases of the staple fresh foods are up a bit, soft drinks, icecream and confectionery only rise by 4.3% (or 5% with road charges).

Of other basic components of household budgets, clothing would rise by 11.2% (11.8%), electricity would jump 10.7% (11.2%), post and telephone services would rise by 8.1% (8.5%) and health services would rise by 22.6% (22.9%).
Price rises of this magnitude would effect every Australian, and every Australian family, and have their greatest impact on those on low incomes and with families to feed and clothe.

It is not only the case that the Opposition is promising to deliver inadequate compensation for the inflationary effect of the consumption tax—it would commit Australia to a permanently higher rate of inflation.

The reason for this is simple: the Opposition has no wages policy. Does it seriously expect low and middle income wage and salary earners of this country to stand idly by while the Opposition under-compensates them while over-compensating high income earners?
Because the Opposition has no wages policy, it will have to rely on tight monetary policy to prevent the demands for compensating wage increases from feeding into higher inflation.

In the end, there would be no choice. Interest rates would have to increase to stop the consumption tax feeding into higher wages and inflation, in turn feeding into higher wage demands, thus triggering a permanent increase in inflation, not the one-off blip the Opposition claims.

Higher interest rates mean higher housing loan rates. If housing loan interest rates increased by 2 percentage points from today's rates, weekly repayments on a $40,000 mortgage would increase by about $13 per week, by about $25 on a $75,000 mortgage and by over $34 for mortgages of $100,000.
These increases virtually absorb all of the Opposition's proposed tax cuts, before taking account of the effects of bracket creep and compensating for the 15 per cent consumption tax.
8. SAVINGS RATIOS

Finally, I have to mention the use of so-called "cameos" or family snapshots by the Opposition to make the shift from income to consumption tax look beneficial and to personalise the "everyone's a winner" theme. They're worth a close look.

Under the Opposition's package, those families which invest more get higher benefits because their income tax is lower and they pay less consumption tax. So in constructing its cameos, the Opposition has picked examples from the Household Expenditure Survey which have high savings ratios so as to artificially reduce the impact of the consumption tax. Treasury has examined these examples and determined the implied savings ratios:

PARA.TAB: Sue and Con, on two incomes totalling $1,878 a week, with 3 children, have a savings ratio of 40%
Mary and Greg, on 1 income of $537 plus Family Allowance of $20 a week, with 2 children, have a savings ratio of 38%
Julie, unemployed, receiving a benefit of $139 a week, has a savings ratio of 26%
Harold and Dulcie, aged pensioners on $252 a week, have a savings ratio of 47%.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite obviously, these savings ratios are absurd: in 1990-91, the average household savings ratio was 6.3%. Is the Opposition seriously suggesting that unemployed persons ought to be saving over a quarter of their unemployment benefit? Does the Opposition really believe that pensioners ought to be saving nearly half their pensions?
9. CONCLUSION

The fundamental and unresolved problems of the Opposition's package go, of course, much further than I have described. There are their defective policies on savings, on superannuation, on micro-economic reform, on wages and on unions.
It is a deeper issue, however, that I now wish to address. It is the question any thinking person has to ask. It is more than a question. It is the heart of the problem.

On the one hand we have in Fightback a package that, does not add up. That is fact. It remains fact, however you like to look at it. That implies that there is something its authors propose to do that they do not want to tell us.

Then there is the extraordinary consequence for the community. Instead of everyone being a winner, as we are told, over 70 per cent of wage and salary earning households in this country will be worse off. Over 60 per cent of farm and self-employed households will be worse off. This is the plan that purports to offer people hope.
You can be certain that these features of Fightback will come as more than a shock for most Liberals, and especially Nationals. Come as a shock it should.
The name of the package is Fightback. But the battle, the fight is being carried not to this Government, which is its supposed object, but to the ordinary households of this country.

Under the banner of giving people more control over their lives, the Opposition package gives ordinary people less. If you have your income diminished, as Fightback promises for the majority, you cannot, I suggest, be having more control over your life.

But under this slogan the Opposition package says to people not just that they should look after themselves more. It says something different. It says: They are on their own. They are on their own to negotiate with their employer; they are on their own to insure themselves for adequate health care.
There are easily identifiable winners and losers in the Hewson Australia. The losers are the labourers, not the lawyers; the nurses, not the neurosurgeons; the teachers, not the tax accountants.
It is not the way that Australia has won its successes in the past. It is a way that promises no success for our future.
And the point is that, with the exception of its ideological leadership—the men driven by dogma—the majority of Liberals and Nationals know that only too well.

They know that their Party can have a durable claim on government only if they have the capacity to govern for all Australians, fairly and equitably; if they can lead a unified people; and if they can maintain a cohesive society.
The most serious and the deepest problem with Fightback is that it can claim none of these things.
The saddest thing about Fightback is that the Opposition is now locked so far into something on which it was misinformed by its leadership, from which it cannot retreat.
Some in the Opposition imagine that they are on a roll. But I remind them that even the Gadarene swine thought the going was good, until they were half-way down.

On this side of the House, we aspire to One Nation: a nation which is rich because of the knowledge, skills and values of its people: a nation which prospers and is capable of making its way in the world: a nation which is humane and provides adequately for the needs of all its people.

This cohesive nation, concerned for its citizens, is very different from the one which would emerge from the Opposition's ideological experiment—an experiment designed to prove the superiority of those in the community who already have a head start.
The clearest conclusions to be drawn from the analysis which I present today is that the Opposition's proposals are basically unfair, which is in sharp contrast to the claims made for them.
The publication of this material will reveal just how unfair these proposals are and I commend a study of these documents to every member of this House and indeed every citizen of this nation.
