Let me say something else about the Four Corners program televised last night. Rarely has the Australian public been presented with such a blatantly politically biased program. The shadow Treasurer was given approximately one hour to look at the Treasury document before he was interviewed on it. The family studies that were included in the first part of the program were not accurately portrayed at all, certainly in their relevance to the coalition's proposals. The use of Ms Louise Sylvan of the Australian Consumers Association to provide assessments of the packages of consumer purchases is a great testimony to the lack of objectivity and the basic bias in those studies.

People should be aware that Ms Sylvan is the Executive Director of the Australian Consumers Association—the largest consumer organisation in Australia, the largest single component of the umbrella body which purports to represent consumer groups in Australia, namely, the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations. Ms Sylvan, through her position on the ACA, is on the AFCO governing council. During the term of the Hawke and Keating governments, AFCO has received more than $1.8m in direct grants. During the 1987 Federal election AFCO declared, `Consumers should vote Labor'. The former chairman of AFCO, Gary Mason, said of AFCO, `Groups like ourselves are the very things the Labor Party is about'. The ALP policy platform explicitly names AFCO as an organisation to be supported.

AFCO has come out publicly and opposed many of the proposals in the coalition's Fightback package, yet the ABC had the stupidity to get a representative from the main organisation within that peak body, AFCO, and then try to purport to the Australian public that its assessment was objective and unbiased. That is an absolutely stupid thing for the ABC to have done. By doing this, it removed any credibility that the program may otherwise have had; that was limited by that.

The other thing to be asked—and it was asked by Senator Bishop in Question Time, and she got an absolutely unacceptable answer from Senator Button—is: how did the ABC get this document? It was a document that was to be produced to the coalition under freedom of information. It was, to that extent, a privileged document. We received that document only now in the Senate, formally through its tabling here. It was requested months ago by the shadow Treasurer. It has not been received, as I say, until today. How did the ABC get that document? When did the ABC get that document? Who gave the ABC that document?

As I understood Senator Button's response to Senator Bishop in Question Time today, Senator Button was `quite convinced it did not come from the Treasury'. Well, there are not too many places that this document could have come from. It could have come from the Treasury, but if it did not come from the Treasury, where else could it have come from? It seems to me that there are only three other places where it could have come from: one, from the Treasurer or his office; two, from the Prime Minister; and, three, if not from the Prime Minister, then from his office. If Senator Button is quite convinced that it did not come from the Treasury, by implication, he is saying that it came out of either the Treasurer's office or the Prime Minister's office.

This just reinforces the view that is widespread throughout the community as of now that one cannot trust this Government, that it has no credibility and that it does nothing other than play political games of the most biased nature. I believe that last night's ABC-Dawkins co-production marks a new low in this Government's corruption of our institutions. In complete defiance of convention, as I said, the Government has supplied material to the media before it released it to Parliament and the Australian public. It is bad enough that the Government used the ABC. It is even worse that the ABC allowed itself to be the Government's tool in this exercise, particularly when it had only a fraction of the material. What about the other 160 pages—indeed, the 400-odd pages that we have now seen today? Why did the Government not give that to the ABC?

What is the Government trying to hide in all this—given that the Treasury head, Tony Cole, the current head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and former Department of Finance Secretary, Mike Keating, and even the Prime Minister's own economist, Dr John Edwards, all back a goods and services tax? Treasury and the Prime Minister's Department wanted a goods and services tax back in 1985. There is only one conclusion to be drawn from all of that: the reason why there was a selective disclosure to the ABC last night was that the Treasury in fact backs Fightback, the coalition's set of proposals.

Indeed, despite all its biases, conceptual errors and incorrect assumptions, the Treasury analysis contained in the document that the ABC had last night gives total endorsement—indeed, more than total endorsement if one can have such a thing—to the goods and services tax and to the measures proposed by the coalition to compensate age pensioners, welfare beneficiaries and other low income earners for the 4.4 per cent, one-off price impact of the introduction of a goods and services tax.

The document acknowledges that the coalition's compensation measures will be more than what is required to compensate for the one-off price effect. Let us have a look at what that price impact will be. On page 3 of its document, the Treasury says of its analysis of the Fightback proposals:

SPEECH.PARA: The analysis suggests that the total CPI impact of the introduction of the GST, the abolition of the wholesale sales tax, fuel excise and payroll taxes, and the changes to health care arrangements, is in the region of 4.6 per cent.
That 4.6 per cent, it says, includes the increased cost of the health care arrangements and the increased cost to smokers of the higher tobacco prices.

PARA.TAB: The coalition has costed those items into the Fightback proposals, but it has not included them in the 4.4 per cent one-off price impact that we have said will result from the GST package. We have a 0.3 per cent impact on the consumer price index of the higher price to smokers and we have an increase in the CPI effect of 0.7 per cent for the change in our proposed health care arrangements. We admit those; they are said quite openly; we have said quite openly that we have made those changes to change the behaviour of the community by discouraging smoking and encouraging a much greater, more efficient use of the health resources of our community.

But those figures were not included in our calculation—deliberately so and openly so—of the price impact of the introduction of the GST. So the Treasury document of last night is saying—because those figures have to be taken off if we are going to compare like with like—that Treasury believes that the price impact of the coalition's proposals will be 3.6 per cent compared with the coalition's own estimate of 4.4 per cent. In other words, it has given us a better mark on the inflation stakes—the critical aspect that we thought the Treasury and the Government were really going to have a go at us on. We thought they would have said that our price impact assessment of 4.4 was too low. In fact, they are saying that it is too high and that we have dealt ourselves a bad card by saying 4.4. They say that it should be only 3.6.

Senator Button got it absolutely wrong today when he responded to Senator Reid's question on the price impact. Indeed, Senator Button's statements today, in his futile attempts to answer questions, were quite extraordinary. He got everything wrong that he attempted to answer. I find it absolutely incredible for Senator Button, one of the key economic Ministers in this Government, to say that he did not know whether the Government had made an assessment of the impact on income distribution of its One Nation document—the Government's economic statement of last week. It simply highlights the totally political nature of this exercise so far as the Government is concerned.

Last week's economic statement by the Government was not an economic statement; it was a blatantly political statement designed to try to buy votes before the Wills by-election in a couple of months. It was a desperate attempt by a desperate Prime Minister to claw up some support in the community for a deeply divided, rattled and desperate government.

The internal inconsistencies in what the Government is saying are legion. As I have said, last night the Government showed that the Treasury analysis of the GST Fightback package was 3.6 per cent. Yet elsewhere in the document—and I will come to this a little later—when it came to try to cost the accuracy of the coalition's proposal to give back to taxpayers any additional revenue that is gained because of the effect of inflation on taxation rates, it used a figure of 6 to 7 per cent as an inflation rate.

There is a basic internal inconsistency there. Why has the Government used 6 to 7 per cent in one breath while admitting in another breath that the real figure of the coalition's measures is 3 to 3 1/2 per cent? Why did it use 6 to 7 per cent for this part of its costing exercise when the whole of its own economic statement is predicated on the basis of an inflation rate over the next three or four years of approximately 3 1/2 per cent? Why the different standards? Why the double standards? Again, one can come to only one conclusion: either this Treasury document was politically manipulated from outside or, if it was not, it contains some fundamental flaws that make it internally very inconsistent.

One of the key criticisms contained in the ministerial statement about the coalition's Fightback proposals relates to the question to which I have just referred of bracket creep; that is, the additional revenue that governments get because of inflation, taking taxpayers from one income tax bracket to a higher income tax bracket. Indeed, a large part of this Government's expenditure programs over the last seven or eight years has been funded simply through this insidious, unfair and inequitable device of bracket creep. This Government has ripped $22 billion off income tax payers in this country through bracket creep.

Today, in response to a question from me at Question Time, Senator Button admitted that there is no provision at all in the One Nation document, the so-called economic statement of last week, to hand back any bracket creep at all by this Government. That answer will be in the Hansard. I do not blame him. If he had not said that, he would have been telling an untruth because the economic statement does not have any provision in it at all for the handing back of bracket creep.

That is in stark contrast to the coalition's Fightback proposals which have totally costed to the cent the handing back of bracket creep; it is included as an integral part of the coalition's proposals. We will legislate to ensure that bracket creep, this unfair tax take by the Government, is handed back to the taxpayers at the end of each financial year. What is more, that is fully costed. Indeed, that is another marked distinction between the Fightback proposals and the Government's proposals, because not in any context at all are the Government's proposals actually funded by other tax or expenditure measures.
The Treasury document shoots down the Government beautifully on this very point. If we look at page 8 of the Treasury document that was used last night on the ABC, we find the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The return of bracket creep is therefore necessary to ensure that people do not pay a greater proportion of their income in tax solely because of inflation.

In other words, the Treasury is saying that if a government is going to be fair it has to give back, it has to allow for, bracket creep. The Government denies the advice and the clear statement of its own Treasury on that issue.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the other area where the Government is totally vulnerable, and rightly so, in relation to its statement last week is in the area of tax cuts. It is absolutely incredible that a Labor government, a government that purports to represent the low income earner in our society, can dare to bring forward a so-called statement of hope for the future, the One Nation statement, which does not allow for one cent of income tax cuts for the 42 per cent of the Australian income tax paying population who earn less than about $20,700. Forty-two per cent of the total population have a taxable income of less than that amount. The Government's tax scales, which will not come in anyway until 1994 and 1996, do not provide any relief at all at that income level.

By contrast, there is a major reduction in the proportion of income tax that will be paid under the coalition's Fightback proposals by low income earners up to that level, including the very low income earners, where we will raise the minimum exemption level, the minimum threshold, from $5,400 to $7,000, thereby exempting totally from the payment of income tax an additional several hundred thousand people who now pay it.

I wish to make only a couple of other points because I want to leave time for my colleagues to participate fully in this debate. Back in 1985, the then Treasurer, now the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, made a very important statement. He was then the most ardent exponent of the very proposals that form the basis of the coalition's Fightback proposals, based around, although much wider than, the introduction of a goods and services tax. In 1985 Mr Keating said that the ideal solution in the reform of the tax system of this country would be the replacement of the wholesale sales tax with a goods and services tax and a capital gains tax and effective closure of major avenues for tax avoidance and minimisation.

I cite that latter statement for a very important reason. Ever since Mr Keating was rolled on his goods and services tax proposal back in 1985, he has been trying to rewrite history by saying that Australia does not now need a goods and services tax because the Government has made changes in the capital gains tax area and has closed off other tax loopholes that existed at that time. His own words absolutely destroy that argument because he predicated the whole of his approach in 1985 on those things occurring in any case. One has to look only at the types of statements the very articulate exponent of the goods and services tax made in 1985, namely, Mr Keating, to know that his supposed opposition to the tax today is something that he does not believe in and, therefore, he has no credibility at all in relation to that proposition.

The document we have as the basis for our debate today, the ministerial statement by the Treasurer, is based on material supplied by the Treasury which is flawed. It is very surprising to see so many mistakes, both conceptual and otherwise, in a document provided by the Treasury. One can only speculate as to the reasons for that. We have a desperate Prime Minister, a desperate government, trying to rake up every scare campaign, every scare tactic, every mistruth, every misleading misrepresentation of the true situation in a desperate attempt to salvage a government which the Prime Minister himself and the Australian people know is going down the drain at a very great rate of knots.

Mr Dawkins, the author of today's statement, but more particularly the Prime Minister, know that they have blown their chance with the economic statement. The statement last week was supposed to give an honest assessment of Australia's economic difficulties and have the courage to make the structural reforms necessary to ensure sustainable growth and jobs. That statement last week showed no courage at all, no such realism, no such opportunity or hope for the future, and failed completely to provide any idea of where this visionless, desperate Prime Minister is trying to lead this country. It was a political statement designed to buy time for the Prime Minister. It was not what it should have been—a responsible economic statement. No attempt to mislead and deceive the Australian public about the content of the coalition's policies will ever change that fact.

Who on earth will believe this Prime Minister, this person who said there would never ever be a recession? He said that two days before the last election, knowing full well that as soon as the election was out of the way the recession would hit. He said in 1988, when he introduced his Budget, that it would not only bring home the bacon but that it would also be `the crowning glory of anything any government has ever produced'. Mr Keating is the man who completely got it wrong over 8 1/2 years as Treasurer. He is the man who produced the greatest misery and hardship for more Australians than this nation has seen in the last 60 years. He is trying now to convince the people of Australia that he has the answers for the future. He did not have the answers in the last nine years. There is no possible reason or expectation that he can have those answers for the future.

This attack by the Government on the coalition's Fightback proposals is not only flawed but is also totally politically biased. I have no doubt at all that it will not stand up because the whole rationale for the attack has no legs, and it will increasingly be revealed that that is the case. Indeed, the extraordinary and very satisfying thing the coalition finds is that, despite the enormous resources the Government has poured into attacking the coalition's Fightback proposal, at great cost to taxpayers, because it is all taxpayer funded—all this work, all this modelling that is going on in Treasury is being funded by the taxpayer—no fault has been found on any single significant count with that package.

That is why the Fightback package has captured the imagination of the Australian people. It shows vision, it is properly costed, and it is an accurate statement. As we go to the next election, the Australian people will continue increasingly to see that as the case and will compare it very starkly, and very bleakly so far as the Government is concerned, with that flawed political attempt last week to even the books—an attempt that I believe has failed quite miserably.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a ministerial statement from the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) which summarises the analysis by the Federal Treasury of the goods and services tax proposal incorporated in the Fightback package of the Liberals. We are not debating a whole range of side issues or diversions. We are not debating how the ABC somehow got hold of a copy of the analysis or whatever. We are debating what is in the ministerial statement and what is in the Treasury analysis.

PARA.TAB: The Treasury analysis of the distributional effects, the effects on real income distribution in Australia of the Fightback package, are illuminating and highly disturbing. This analysis by the Federal Treasury shows that the Liberal Party package is highly regressive, highly unfair, with the most resources in net terms going to high income earners. I stress at the outset that this study has not been done by the Government; it has not been done by the Executive Government of Australia. It has been done by the Treasury Department of the Australian Public Service. It should be treated on that basis and we should not get sucked into all the side issues, diversions and hares that Senator Short tried to run this afternoon about how the ABC somehow got hold of the contents of this or some other side issue.

This afternoon Senator Short tried to ignore the devastating findings of this independent analysis by the Australian Public Service, showing, for example, that as a result of the Fightback package of Dr Hewson some seven out of 10 full time wage and salary earners in Australia will be worse off and only three out of 10 will be better off.

Looking at the self-employed category in Australia—self-employed persons and farmers—on the Treasury analysis six out of 10 will be worse off and only four out of 10 will be better off. That is what will happen according to this thoroughgoing analysis of all the assumptions, all the underlying parameters, of the Opposition's package. Yet I recall that late last year when Dr Hewson announced this so-called Fightback package he said that everybody would win under it, everybody would be better off. These figures today nail that lie very conclusively indeed. Clearly, Dr Hewson was wrong. Clearly, he was misleading the Australian electorate when he said that everybody wins under the Fightback package.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to run your policies through?

—We do not have a goods and services tax in our policy. We will get onto the distributional effects of this package in a moment. The reality is that we will not slug the products and services sold in the Australian economy with a 15 per cent value added tax. That is the thing that really creates the massive unfairness, the massive negative distributional effects of this Fightback package that we are looking at today.

PARA.TAB: Dr Hewson tried the old Liberal Party hardy of a fist full of dollars, the idea being that one wins elections by bribing the electorate with massive personal income tax cuts. That is, of course, what Malcolm Fraser tried in 1977. This is the centrepiece, it seems, of the Liberal Party's election strategy for the next Federal election.

However, when we look at the figures in this package, when we look at the details, we find that, allowing for the effect of the 15 per cent consumption tax in line with these personal income tax reductions, only households with taxable incomes above $40,000—and I did not say $14,000; I said $40,000—receive net benefits from the proposed Liberal Party package. Households with incomes above $40,000 are those which will be better off. In other words, those with incomes less than $40,000 will be worse off. Of course, if the Opposition's consumption tax were ever implemented, we would have to look at the effects of the massive kick start to inflation it would cause by cancelling out the personal income tax cuts for those with a taxable income of more than $40,000.

When we look at the top end of the distribution of income—say, incomes of $100,000 or more—we see that persons receiving those sorts of salaries receive double the compensation that they need for the price rises from the consumption tax under this package. The largest benefits go to those on the highest incomes in Australia. Of course, that is no surprise to most of us on this side of the Chamber. We know that the Liberal Party supports the big end of town. It supports those who earn high incomes. They are certainly the people who receive the biggest benefit out of this package.

When the Treasury looked at the fine print of the Fightback package, when it looked at the details and the assumptions, it discovered that the Liberals had omitted some important elements from their own analysis of the impact of the package on the distribution of real income. There were several major areas omitted by the Liberals in this package which impacted significantly on the distribution of real income in Australia. The items that tended to be left out by the Liberals were, in fact, items which most hurt lower and middle income households. They tended to omit from their distributional analysis items in the package which would impact most negatively on lower and middle income households.

I refer, firstly, to expenditure cuts. The reality of government spending is that high income earners depend less on government spending for their welfare than lower income earners. High income earners do not rely so much on the Budget for their living standards as lower income earners. The Liberals are, in fact, proposing massive expenditure cuts in their package. Prima facie, one would expect that the impact of those expenditure cuts would be on the lowest income earners. In fact, even on the Liberal Party's own costings, some $6.5 billion worth of expenditure cuts has not really been taken into account in its own distributional calculations. Those cuts, essentially, were focused through social security transfer payments—income payments—to lower income households.

Then, of course, the Liberals have not properly costed bracket creep—the movement of wage and salary earners from one tax bracket into another as a result of wage increases. The actual increase in tax collections is $3 billion, a figure which was not fully taken into account by the Liberals in their assessment of the distributional effects on Australian households.

When we look at the individual expenditure cuts which have not been treated fully and significantly by the Liberals in their package, we look at items such as the removal of Medicare bulkbilling for most households. Obviously, that has distributional effects. The Liberals are also proposing a lower family allowance income test. That would have significant distributional effects. They are proposing a family income test for the dependent spouse rebate. Again, that would have an important effect on the distribution of real income in Australia.

The bottom line to all this is that the Treasury analysis is very conservative. That is the nature of the institution. That policy-making department of the Australian Public Service is, essentially, a fairly conservative institution. It has made a conservative analysis of the effect on Australian households of the Fightback package. The Treasury actually pointed out that its analysis would understate the number of households in Australia that would be worse off under that package.

As I pointed out at the beginning of my remarks, some seven out of 10 of all full-time wage and salary earners in Australia would be worse off under this Liberal package. What the Treasury analysis shows is that that is a very conservative figure. The figure is probably more than seven out of 10.

Speaking before me this afternoon, Senator Short said that the Treasury analysis was flawed. I assume that he was using the word `flawed' with a `w' in it, but I must say, after listening to his speech, I believe that the Treasury document has certainly floored the Liberal Party—`floored' with a double `o'—because, clearly, it has set the Liberal Party on a path of running hares and creating diversionary tactics. The Liberal Party is trying to focus this debate on how the ABC got hold of the analysis, rather than on the real point here, which is the effect on the distribution of Australian income between households on different incomes.

It is a very floored Liberal Party we faced this afternoon as it tries to get out from under this assault by the Treasurer on its document, showing how unfair it is in terms of the distribution of income in Australia. We all know that the Liberal Party package is regressive anyway. We only have to look at the consumption tax to see how regressive a proposal it would be. The Liberal Party in this country is proposing a full-blooded value added tax. Nothing less than that; a full-blooded value added tax—

TALK.START.PARA: —Like most other countries.

—We will get onto that in a moment, Senator Kemp, because that is exactly the point I was going to make next. It is not like most other countries. These people opposite want a full-blooded value added tax. They want a tax that would be draconian. They are proposing a most draconian, inflexible and non-selective tax. They want a tax on consumption that is tougher than the value added tax that most persons born in the United Kingdom and living in Australia have come to know and dislike. The Liberals' tax proposal is much tougher than the value added taxes operated in countries overseas.

PARA.TAB: Before I get onto the specifics of that, I might just point out that the Liberal Party wants to abolish the present system of the wholesale sales tax and then bring in this particular 15 per cent consumption tax. I point out, for example, that the present sales tax is very narrow. For example, it does not tax services. It focuses, essentially, on physical products. It is a selective tax, so that luxuries are taxed at a higher rate than basic necessities.

I might point out that the Australian Taxpayers Association, with Mr Eric Risstrom as its national director, has worked out that only about $1 in every $4 spent in the Australian economy at present is hit by the current sales tax. That is a fairly simple proposition—only $1 in every $4 spent in the Australian economy at present is affected by sales tax. Yet these people opposite want a 15 per cent tax on virtually everything—every physical product, every service, everything consumed in the Australian economy. Those are some of the points that we have to bear in mind when we look at this proposal of the Liberal Party.

Basically, the present system is selective to the extent that, since last week, it taxes ordinary passenger motor vehicles at the rate of 15 per cent. It has a selective rate of 30 per cent on luxury motor vehicles. So that tax is quite selective. In fact, it is hardly regressive when one looks at it in those terms.

The Liberals want to have an equal rate of tax of 15 per cent both on the luxury motor car and on the ordinary standard passenger motor vehicle. The tax that the Labor Government has in place, the sales tax, is levied at a rate of 30 per cent on items such as processed diamonds, jewellery and furs. The Liberals will tax those items at 15 per cent. The great bulk of food and clothing items consumed in the Australian economy and consumed significantly by low income households are tax free under the Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about services consumed by the rich?

—We will get to that in a moment. On the subject of food, it is interesting that the Australian Bureau of Statistics every three months monitors the price of 44 staple food items around Australia. It looks at a list of items which are consumed fairly heavily by Australian households. It is very illuminating that only two of the 44 items monitored by the Bureau face a sales tax. Therefore, 42 out of 44 food items which are regarded as key staple items by the Bureau of Statistics do not have a sales tax levied on them at present, but the Liberals would tax all those items at a rate of 15 per cent. It is interesting that virtually all food items consumed in the Australian economy would go up in price as a result of the Liberal Party proposal. There are only a couple of snack foods that would be affected in a different way under that Liberal proposal.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that the Liberals want a tax of 15 per cent on all goods and services; they want a tax at each stage of production. They would bring in the first Australian tax of a comprehensive nature on services. They would bring in a tax on gas bills and telephone bills, a tax on hairdressers, a tax on accountants as well as a tax on physical products consumed in the Australian economy.

Let me take a typical telephone bill in my State of South Australia, which is $520 at present. The 15 per cent tax would increase that bill to $598. That is the sort of impact that the goods and services tax would have in the Australian economy. The Liberals are proposing a tax with a very broad base. They would give very few exemptions because they are desperate to maximise the revenue that they want from that tax. Virtually everything sold in the Australian economy would be taxed at a rate of 15 per cent.

It is interesting, in view of earlier interjections from Senator Kemp, to look at the Liberals' tax proposals in an international context. The value added tax imposed by the conservatives in the United Kingdom—the Tories, the ultra-right like Mrs Thatcher in that country—gave exemptions for food, gas and power bills, bus fares, children's clothes, books and newspapers. All those items were exempted from value added tax under the Tories, the right wing conservatives in the United Kingdom. However, the Liberals would tax all those items in Australia. Every one of those items would be within the tax net under this draconian, non-selective and inflexible proposal brought down by Dr Hewson.

The Liberals would tax food, gas and power bills, public transport fares, children's clothes and books and newspapers. Things like public transport fares and children's clothes are significant items in the budgets of lower and middle income households. We are talking today about the effects on the distribution of income and the real impact on household welfare, and a tax on things such as bus fares and children's clothes would impact significantly on lower income households in Australia. That is in the international context, making a comparison with the United Kingdom.

Let us look at Canada, which is a country the Liberals looked at in coming out with their harebrained scheme. Again, in Canada there is an exemption for basic foodstuffs. The Canadian goods and services tax brought in about a year ago exempts basic foodstuffs. That is one way in which the Canadians have worked to ensure that the impact of the tax proposals on lower income and middle income households is reduced.

Let us also look at some of the countries in continental Europe such as France, Germany and Switzerland. They do not have just a 15 per cent rate on everything as the Hewson Liberals would have—an inflexible, draconian, non-selective tax of 15 per cent on everything. In France, Germany and Switzerland the VAT systems have multiple rates, with a low rate on the basic necessities of life, the basic essentials consumed by households, which are often exempt from tax, and higher rates of tax on luxury goods consumed in those economies. But again in the international context we are seeing here under the Liberals a very non-selective, draconian and inflexible tax proposal which would hit every household with a 15 per cent tip for Dr Hewson every time people spend money at a supermarket or at some other shop in the community.

After all, it is a tax on spending, because that is what it is all about. Therefore, it hits those families who spend all or most of their income harder than other households. We all know which families spend all or most of their incomes. It is the lower and middle income households in our community. Every time a household is able to save a dollar of income, it is able to avoid the goods and services tax, but those households that spend all their income or more are paying tax on every dollar of that income. It is a much more draconian approach to taxation than is personal income tax.

It is very illuminating that low income earners in Australia spend a very high proportion of their incomes on food, clothing and services. That is the reality which is shown by the household expenditure studies and budget studies. But we know that at the moment those areas are tax free. They are free from sales tax. No sales tax is levied on those areas by the Keating Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did over Bob. You got your policy so right you dumped your PM.

—And there was none levied by the Hawke Government prior to that, but we know that those items are significant in the purchasing of lower and middle income households. The last budget study I saw from the Bureau of Statistics showed that some 32 per cent of all the outlays of lower and middle income households was on food, clothing and footwear, but only 9 per cent of the spending by the highest income households in Australia went on those items. We know that the categories of food, clothing and footwear will face some of the biggest price rises, if the Liberals ever get in to adopt their harebrained policies.

PARA.TAB: Meanwhile we will see the ultimate inequity and unfairness as a result of this particular tax proposal. While the basic necessities of life—and we are talking here about distribution and fairness—such as food and clothing will face price rises of up to 15 per cent as a result of this Liberal proposal, we would see a number of luxury goods—goods purchased by high income earners in our community—face significant price falls. Luxury cars retailing at above $45,000 currently are slugged by a 30 per cent sales tax by the Labor Government, and I support that sales tax on those particular motor vehicles, but Dr Hewson—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this part of the Button car plan?

—Senator Kemp is just not with it. In addition to trying to replace a 30 per cent sales tax on luxury cars with a 15 per cent general tax on ordinary family sedans as well as on luxury vehicles, those opposite are also putting out press releases telling us to accelerate our rate of tariff reduction for a range of industries. I have in my possession a press release from Mr Ian McLachlan demanding that we accelerate the rate of tariff reduction for a whole range of industries.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp would do a lot of things to the industry. He would encourage more people to buy luxury motor vehicles because the price margin caused by the sales tax as between the 30 per cent tax and the 15 per cent tax would be reduced and made negligible. Therefore, a number of people who were looking previously at buying domestically produced standard motor vehicles would not do so but would buy cheaper luxury cars. That is what Senator Kemp would do to the motor industry. He would generate an offshore sales boom in motor vehicles because people would substitute locally produced cars with overseas cars priced above $45,000.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition is putting forward a very unfair proposal. I find it indefensible that the Opposition can propose the same rate of tax on margarine and Mercedes, the same rate of tax on yoghurt and yachts. There will be many complications as a result of the Opposition's proposal; there will be a number of weird price effects if the coalition ever gets into power. The Opposition will create a situation where luxury goods come down in price but the basic essentials—food, clothing and footwear—become more expensive for most households in the Australian community.

We have heard the Liberals say, `Oh well, we shouldn't be too hung up on the distributional effects of our package because, after all, we are going to compensate households for our 15 per cent goods and services tax. We'll boost household payments through social security and we'll give personal income tax cuts to compensate households for the effect of our 15 per cent tax'. That is the rhetoric. I find it incredible that the Opposition expects the electorate to believe what it says.

Look at New Zealand. In 1986 the New Zealand Government—a Labour Government—went to the electorate and said, `Look, we need to bring in a 10 per cent consumption tax in New Zealand, but don't worry about it—we'll compensate you fully; we'll give you an increase in your social security payments. Don't worry about it, trust us. We'll cut your personal income tax if you are in the work force. Don't worry about it, we'll compensate you for any price rises occasioned by these particular taxes'. The electorate was sold that proposition.

The tax rate went from 10 per cent to 12 1/2 per cent in a three-year period. But was there any talk about extra compensation for the population? Was there any pledge by the Government there to increase social security payments? Was there any pledge to further reduce personal income taxes to compensate for the extra price rises? There was none at all. This is the great problem with these taxes: they are brought in as enormous panaceas by conservative politicians but time and time again the rates have been put up with no corresponding compensation for the electorate.

The package proposed by those opposite is nothing short of a recipe for disaster for this country, because it would mean a significant increase in inflation, a resultant increase in interest rates, an increase in unemployment—and the Opposition admits that—and a reduction in economic growth. PARA.TAB: It was interesting to note that only three pages were devoted to industrial relations in the Fightback package, and I accept the assurances that the Opposition will come clean with the proposed industrial relations legislation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Three pages out of 600.

PARA.TAB: What is the secret agenda of those opposite? Of course, what they intend to do is to make sure, in a quite brutal fashion, that workers cannot catch up and cannot restore their purchasing power. They intend to do that by introducing industrial relations legislation similar to that which has been introduced in New Zealand. They intend to introduce individual contracts. Of course, one of the sectors of the economy that has grown significantly over the last decade, and all through this recession, has been the tourism industry. We have seen a massive growth in jobs. TALK.START.PARA: —Wholesale sales tax, payroll tax.

—How about the cost of wholesale sales tax on sheets, towels, soap?
—Senator Knowles should not panic so much over there. She is worried; we can see it on her face. We know she is worried that she is not getting her message through, but she should not panic.
—We are not worried about you—not little wimps like you.

—Order! Senator Knowles, I do not notice your name on the speakers list. If you would like to put yourself on it, I am sure that you will be given the opportunity to speak at a later stage. But at the moment Senator Sherry has the call.

—Those opposite are touchy today. The last week has been a bad one for them and the next 52 weeks before the next election will be a lot worse. In terms of the legitimate problems of the tourism industry, the Government is tackling the issue of depreciation write-offs, extending accelerated depreciation and addressing the issue of promotion. What has the Opposition proposed? It has proposed absolutely nothing for the tourism and hospitality industries. I will now outline the Opposition proposals that stand in stark contrast to what has been proposed by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the One Nation package. PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot's accusation that we are not addressing the problems that lower income families face is untrue. Over the last eight years we have provided significant tax changes for that group of people in our community. In this document we have also targeted special assistance to families. The Government is also proposing, as part of the One Nation package, to tackle the severe infrastructure problems that this country faces in terms of roads, rail and ports. We are also proposing to tackle the significant education and training problems that this country faces.

In summation, the policy that has been put forward by those opposite is a recipe for disaster. It is a recipe for a divided nation—a nation where the strong will exploit the weak. It is a recipe for an increase in inflation, interest rates, unemployment and a declining economy, a la New Zealand. We have a perfect working example in New Zealand—and I use the word `working' very loosely when describing New Zealand because that country's whole economy is falling apart. The Opposition boasts that this is what it wants to introduce into the Australian economy.

In terms of the tourism industry, which I highlighted earlier, the Government has introduced improved capital write-offs over 25 years, not 40 years. So the Government has very carefully targeted an industry that has very substantial long term growth prospects. Along with those measures are our aviation reforms. The tourism industry is a good example of what the Government has been doing and what we intend to do, which is in total contrast to those opposite who intend to absolutely implode the hospitality industry and destroy any job prospects.

The future is very clear: it is either Fightback!—the Doomsday book, as I refer to it—or One Nation. There is a very clear contrast between the two. I am very confident that, as the next year wears on—and certainly there are looks of panic on the faces of those opposite—that One Nation will be the choice at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's ministerial statement has brought back classroom memories of maths teachers who stressed—and, I might say, not too pleasantly at times—that one could not judge the correctness of an answer until one had seen the method of arriving at it. I believe that it is blatantly obvious that the method applied in this case was simple: decide an answer and work backwards to arrive at it.

PARA.TAB: That being the case, judging the correctness of the Treasury analysis is just as simple: it is not correct. That is really somewhat disheartening, given the power of Treasury irrespective of whichever party is in power. Being the humble senator that I am, I did not expect to come across figures in the analysis which take fewer than 10 fingers to count and find that the so-called financial and economic brain-box of the nation cannot get them right. If Treasury's financial wizards can no longer count, Australia is in deeper trouble than we thought.

I draw your attention, Mr Acting Deputy President, to the fact that we have a foreign debt that has gone out to $185 billion. Treasury officers over the years advised former Treasurer Keating, now Prime Minister Keating, that we were not going to have a recession. He said that he would not let us have a recession. It then became the recession that we had to have for our own good. Some 12 months ago we were told that we were coming out of the recession, that business was starting to restock, that all was well and that the indicators were right.

One assumes that this advice was given to the former Treasurer and now Prime Minister by Treasury officers. This advice, which has been repeated in the Parliament, has been clearly and substantially wrong in the past. One also assumes that these are the same Treasury officers who have been advising the Government on the basis of the coalition's Fightback package and the documentation that has been tabled today.

It is interesting to note that the pages in this documentation are not numbered. This would lead one to suggest and perhaps appreciate that a lot of pages in between have not been included. Clearly, the reason that the pages are not in the Treasury document is that they would substantially support everything the coalition is saying. But, no, the Government has tabled a document after a couple of months. It has whited out page numbers so that people cannot check which pages are in it and which pages have been left out. It has then put it on the table and said, `Well, Treasury has done a job on you. Treasury has cleaned you up'.

The Government has been selective—just like our embassy in Tokyo has been a little selective. We have received a report on the multifunction polis from the Japanese investment mission in Australia. Between the Japanese version of the mission's report and the English translation, which was done by our embassy in Tokyo—

TALK.START.PARA: —Under whose instruction?

—That is the interesting point: under whose instruction did the embassy change it? The Japanese version of the report talked of the multifunction polis as being a dream, but the English version changed the word `dream' to `potential'. My point is that the Japanese version and the English version of the report, which was translated in the Australian Embassy in Tokyo, are quite different.

PARA.TAB: Whose instruction was it to doctor that document? Whose instruction is it that we get pages with the numbers blocked out so that we do not know where the complete documentation is? Once again—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to give us something on merit? Are you going to tell us something about merit soon? Argue substance. Give us an argument on substance.
—When one strikes a chord with members of the Government, they start coming back in to fight and interject.
—Give us some substance.

—We will get into substance in a minute. The Government has had months to work up its proposals, but all it can come up with is documentation that has the pages whited out. I have no doubt that in Treasury or in the Prime Minister's office there are a number of pages which give total support to the direction and some of the assumptions contained in the coalition's Fightback package. So what we have is a piece of advice that simply does not add up.

PARA.TAB: Let us take inflation. Will it be the 3.5 per cent inflation rate in 1993-94, as One Nation claims, or, for the sake of the argument, do we take the Treasury Fightback analysis figure of 6 to 7 per cent? If we believe Treasury's 6 or 7 per cent, then Paul Keating's 3.5 per cent is blatantly unbelievable, politically opportunistic and a stance to make his scenarios work—or appear to work—in theory.

But if we believe Mr Keating—and I suppose that we should try—then a totally incompetent Treasury is giving two different answers to the same mathematical calculation. I note that the Minister is not interjecting in respect of that technical factor concerning the documentation. He has gone silent all of a sudden. Even worse, they have deliberately falsified that rate to make the Fightback package look bad.

The one conclusion that is self-evident is that the Government cannot have it both ways. The use of dodgy statistics to frighten families already battle weary from the present recession is hardly edifying behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hang on. This is Treasury; these are professional officers.

—While it is essential that today we comprehensively debate in this chamber the validity and bias of the Treasury's Fightback analysis, it is just as vital that we do not let the continuing public debate degenerate into a battle of economic technocrats. That is exactly what the Government would want us to do—get the whole issue submerged in confusion about numbers, about figures, and ignore the impact on people and individuals. That is the objective of the Government.
—No.

—Well, it is the same as the objective of the Government last week, when day by day the Prime Minister brought up different issues. If we have a recession, is it not better to have it on page 10 rather than page 1? How do we get the recession to page 10 from page 1? Talk about a range of extraneous matters, as the Prime Minister did last week, quite deliberately, tactically.
—I'd go gracefully, if I were you. You lost last week.

—I am just pointing up what the tactics were. The Government has had the recession on page 1 for month after month after month. Its tactics last week were to range over a number of subjects to push the recession off page 1 and get other matters on page 1.

PARA.TAB: The community outside this building, the people whom the arguments and the equations ultimately affect, neither comprehend nor are interested in an unending line of disagreements and accusations and rebuttals about percentage points, GDPs, CPIs, wholesale sales taxes, et cetera. They simply want a job, good food on the table, and a secure lifestyle. Realistically, that is what we are here to ensure is provided and, more importantly, it is what they have a right to expect from their politicians, their Government.

I believe the reform of our country's taxation system, as set out in Fightback!, can be achieved. I have no faith that One Nation could go anywhere near it. After all, it would seem logical that, if all the cohesive One Nation rhetoric had true substance, it would have effectively addressed the problems of small business instead of tinkering around the edges and achieving next to nothing for small business. But it did not.

We all know that small business is the very engine room of this country's economy. We also know that it is difficult to move anywhere fast if the engine is not operating. One Nation has turned its back on the very sector of the community that accounts for 96 per cent of all Australian business, half of private sector employment, and 30 per cent of GDP. Yet it still expects the country to rise with One Nation like a phoenix from the ashes. It has turned its back on the sector of the community which more than any other has suffered greatly from the recession, with escalating bankruptcies and ongoing redundancies. More than 820,000 businesses have been left to struggle yet again.

We keep hearing from the Labor Party of its love, concern and affinity for the little people in the community. So where is its love, concern and affinity for the small business community? Is it that the Government feels that it can ignore its plight because the redundancies there come in twos, threes and fives and not hundreds and, therefore, attract little media attention, even when the final number becomes massive across Australia? Is it because the Government finds it easier to accept the myth of the small business operator with his Mercedes and mansion rather than the truth, which is that Labor's policies mean that most small business people go home at the end of the week with less money in their pockets than their employees—if, indeed, they are able to take any money home in their pockets in the current circumstances.

Whatever the reason, One Nation makes no attempt to address the fundamental problems of a group of people without whom we cannot expect to kick-start the economy in this country. Unless and until small business gets some breathing space—until it has the capacity to retain some of its earnings; until it has the capacity to improve its liquidity, increase its investment, increase its job opportunities, increase its turnover and increase its stock—we will not get this economy moving in this country.

Fightback! rightly embraces small business as an integral component of its recovery program. The contrast between the two packages is glaring, and I have not found that calculation anywhere in the Treasury's Fightback analysis. I wonder why. Why is it silent on the effects on small business? With Fightback! we will cut overall taxes to business by at least $20 billion while reducing tax on exporters by $1.7 billion. We will abolish the wholesale sales tax system, the debilitating payroll tax—the tax we pay for the privilege of paying someone else a wage—and the training guarantee levy. We plan new capital gains tax arrangements, including the provision of more generous roll-over relief, and relief from capital gains tax on the sale of goodwill.

The Beddall report is the blueprint for the Government. The reason Mr Beddall was made the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs, I assume, was to implement the recommendations of the report. We have not seen much of that. Basically, it has been ignored by Treasury in Budget after Budget. The Fightback package contains components and in some instances goes further than the recommendations of that report. Fuel excise will be abolished, customs duty phased out, and depreciation provisions reviewed. These policies without doubt plan to create a new business climate where small business is no longer treated by government as a second class citizen. In other words, they recognise the role the small business person has in the Australian community—the capacity to employ, the capacity to expand and the capacity to contribute to GDP.

Small business should be treated with the care and respect that I think befits its position as the engine room of the economy. GST certainly will be easier for small business to administer than is the wholesale sales tax. One only has to go out and talk to small business people about the problems of administration of the wholesale sales tax system in this country and the difficulties and the bookkeeping and the nightmare that that creates for small business operators. GST on most business operating costs will be refunded in full. No business input costs will incur tax, and that is a very big break for the business community. Small business will receive significant cash flow advantages from GST funds on business inputs. Tax deductibility on capital equipment because of the GST will be of particular benefit to small businesses who use the opportunity of the tax changeover to upgrade or to move to computer accounting. It is a whole new vista for small business—an even break, a fair break, a new start.

So what of One Nation? `Not much' is the only reply we can give. It fails to secure the one thing most needed to encourage the expansion and development of small business—a capital gains tax roll-over. It fails to address crippling business costs such as fuel prices, payroll tax and the training guarantee levy. The increase in the exemption for goodwill is what we would describe as half-hearted and lacking in effect, while the increase in the eligibility threshold merely compensates for the impact of inflation since the capital gains tax was first introduced. Funding for export measures has been increased by helping only an estimated 700 of more than 820,000 small businesses in this country. That is certainly not going to give us our export-led recovery.

Today I suppose I could have used just as easily the example of the many Australians with an income of under $20,000. That too would have indicated the vast differences in approach between the Fightback package and the Government's One Nation. Fightback has ensured security with tax cuts and compensation; even Monday's Four Corners program had to admit that point. They have simply been ignored in Labor's One Nation statement, left to drift, no doubt in the valiant hope that Labor's traditional base will not swap sides, no matter how bad the economic situation.

It shows that the coalition, through the Fightback package, is about people. Labor is about power at all costs, using mirrors, cynically targeted handouts or Treasury analysis that simply does not add up. This reply to Fightback is a Labor Party attempt at a smokescreen of the real issues of how these policies will go down and affect individuals. The Labor Party wants the debate centred on the heavy economic arguments of the technocrats, which the average person cannot grasp, relate to or comprehend.

The Labor Party wants to confuse the debate in that way, but it will not work. We have had years of recession. In 1988, 1989 and 1990, we had the high interest rate policy of Paul Keating as Treasurer, now Prime Minister. That not only destroyed the hopes, dreams and ambitions of the ordinary Australian trying to buy his or her own home but also absolutely crippled the small business community of this country by forcing it into record levels of bankruptcies and turning hundreds of thousands of Australians onto the unemployment queues. That was all done on the basis of the policy direction of the Labor Party.

The Labor Party does not want the electorate to be reminded of that. But the electorate will not have to be reminded because it will well remember the policy direction of Paul Keating and his predictions of, `Trust me, I will guide you through this. Trust me, we won't have a recession; I won't let there be a recession. Trust me, this is the recession we had to have'. The electorate will remember that come the next election, even though it is twelve months away. The electorate will remember the hurt that has been inflicted upon it by Labor Party policies.

The electorate is looking for an alternative, is looking for a better deal, and is wanting to be convinced of that deal. For the first time in political history in this country we have an Opposition, 18 months from an election, that is prepared to put out a detailed policy analysis and direction of 650 pages. It is a new signpost for this decade to the turn of the century. It is a signpost to the future of how there can be a better deal for all Australians, how to return incentives to Australians and how to increase productivity by giving incentives to the most important people who will bring about productivity, namely, individuals in the Australian economy—not the highfalutin words contained in the Minister's reply today but down to basics, down to what will generate real change for the benefit of Australians, namely, a fair go and a fair deal for individual Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an old saying in politics that there are lies, damned lies and statistics. In the statement delivered today by the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, we find a smattering of all three. The fundamental thrust of the Dawkins' response to the coalition's tax reform package is that the Government will selectively cull the figures, set up the model to suit itself so it knows the outcome well in advance, then produce the outcome and say, `Hey presto, the coalition's tax reform package is no good'.

PARA.TAB: That will not wash. The electorate will just not tolerate this Government continually being selective with its figures, continually trying to hide the truth and continually trying to obscure from the sight of ordinary Australians what is patently obvious in this country at the moment and that is that the policies of this Government, as practised over the past eight to 10 years, have been a manifest failure.

Why should we, after all the political grandstanding of our former Treasurer and now Prime Minister (Mr Keating), believe anything he has to say in his One Nation statement? Why should we believe that after eight years as Treasurer, having led us into the worst recession since the 1930s and suddenly having assumed the office of Prime Minister and taken up residence in The Lodge, he has been given some sort of omniscience and knows all the answers to all our problems? The truth is that Paul Keating knows no more answers now than he did before.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! On quite a few occasions since I have been in the Chair I have overlooked the use of titles. The Prime Minister has a title and so do all members of this House and of the House of Representatives. Would you please use it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, Mr Acting Deputy President. The Prime Minister in fact has many titles; I will not repeat them all here.
—`Jellyback', too!

—The old one was called `Jellyback'. The current one, of course, has many titles as well; I need not go into them, but assume we will call him Mr Keating. Mr Keating knows no more now than Mr Keating knew when he was the failed Treasurer of this nation, than Mr Keating knew when he was the man who stabbed Mr Hawke in the back; and Mr Keating clearly does not have the answers that this country needs to get out of recession.

PARA.TAB: Let us see what Mr Dawkins has to say in trying to bail out his friend Mr Keating, because it is very interesting politics. Less than a week after Mr Keating brought down his One Nation statement, he felt it necessary to have his Treasurer bring down another statement to try to dig him out of the mess he so patently ended up in.

Let us do a quick analysis of how the Treasury has managed to distort the figures in the coalition's tax reform package. I can do no better than quote the Treasury. In document No. 2 there is a long diatribe by Treasury, which says this about expenditure changes:

SPEECH.PARA: A complete analysis of the distributional effects of the Opposition's package would require that the effects of all the Opposition's proposed changes be distributed to households. That would require that account be taken of—

inter alia, all expenditure changes, all tax changes, policy changes and bracket creep. It goes on to say that it does not intend to do so. So all the big savings to this nation's economy that the coalition has proposed, all the big savings in cutting $20 billion off taxation in this nation, have been conveniently left out of the Treasury analysis. That is great! That is like starting a 100 metre dash with one leg amputated. It really is quite ludicrous. Then it goes on to say in respect of the other aspects of the expenditure changes:
While it is not possible to impute to households the impact of all expenditure cuts and revenue measures, the Treasury analysis has taken into account—

and it lists a number, including the introduction of the proposed family income test, lowering the income test threshold for family allowance and so on. The Treasury has looked at all of the ways in which some people may have less money in their pockets and said, `That will be the same for everybody from one end of this country to the other, no matter what sector of the economy they are in'. The Government has amputated one of the legs of the runner and has put a ball and chain around the other, got the gun and said, `Now go'.

PARA.TAB: That will not do. We are all a little bit too intelligent for that. I do not believe anybody in this country will really take this analysis seriously. But in case they do, in case they are foolish enough to believe what Mr Dawkins and Mr Keating—the failed Treasurer and now Prime Minister of this country—have to say, let us look at one simple fact. In its analysis of the coalition's package, Treasury has said that inflation between now and the introduction of our reforms will be 6 per cent to 7 per cent. That is very interesting because last week, according to the Prime Minister, inflation was going to be 3.5 per cent between now and 1994. So we have Treasury on one side saying that between now and 1994 inflation will be 7 per cent and on the other side we have the Prime Minister saying, `Listen, I am such a great bloke that between now and 1994 inflation will be 3.5 per cent'.

Which one will we believe? Will we believe the gobbledegook from the failed Treasurer and now Prime Minister of this country or will we believe what Treasury has to say? We will believe one or the other, or maybe neither. Clearly, this Government cannot even get its distortions right. There is a good old saying that a liar has to have a good memory. That saying applies equally to this Government as it does to all other people who do not wish to tell the truth.

Obviously the Government has to tell us, it has to somehow work out, how to correlate the 7 per cent inflation figure offered by the Treasury and the 3.5 per cent inflation figure offered by the Prime Minister. If the Treasury figure is correct, if 7 per cent is the inflation rate between now and 1994, then every single expenditure item in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement will be wrong as well. It will be wrong by 3.5 per cent per annum, and it will be wrong by 7 per cent between now and 1994.

Clearly the Prime Minister needs to go back and do his homework. Either inflation will be 3.5 per cent, in which case either the whole basis of the Treasury analysis of the coalition's tax reform package is wrong, or the Treasury is right and Mr Keating is wrong in his expenditure figures. It is one or the other. Very clearly, the Prime Minister has his facts wrong and he needs to get them right.
Let us look at something of considerable interest to many people in regional Queensland, and that is road user charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regional Australia, you mean.

—In regional Australia, as Senator Boswell says. Road user charges are of principal interest to people in regional Australia. It will be recalled that when the tax reform package came out, the former Prime Minister of this country, Mr Hawke, tried to scare everybody by saying that the coalition would introduce massive road user charges that were not included in the tax reform package. What the former Prime Minister was referring to, of course, was the Government's own proposal for increasing road user charges in this country, which the Government took to the Special Premiers Conference.

PARA.TAB: I need not remind honourable senators that the Government is proposing to increase the road user charges on every single heavy vehicle in this country by up to $14,400 per annum. These were the figures that the former Prime Minister attributed to the Opposition. Of course, the fact that that was not the case was totally irrelevant to Mr Hawke, his Cabinet Ministers and the aNiMaLS who ran around the Press Gallery, lying to people. It was also totally irrelevant to Mr Hawke and his Cabinet Ministers and aNiMaLS, who again ran around the Press Gallery lying to people, that the coalition in fact opposed the Government's proposed legislation to implement those increased charges.

But here is the real rub about the lies from the former Prime Minister. The analysis that the Treasury made of the hypothetical increase in road user charges was based on the false assumption that the coalition would introduce an increase in road user charges of $2,238 per annum—a figure plucked out of the air with no basis for it. Even if that analysis were right, there is a huge difference between that figure and the Government's own figure of $14,400 for every single heavy vehicle in this country, a figure which Mr Hawke was touting around the Press Gallery and blaming on the Opposition, while not having the honesty to say that that was what the Government was going to do.

In the model that the Treasury people have put together there are some serious flaws in the way they have calculated the necessity to increase road user charges by $2,238 per annum per heavy vehicle. The major flaw is, of course, that the Treasury people, scratching around desperately to try to find a bit of muck to throw, decided that they were going to blur the distinctions as to how we fund the roads in this nation. They said, `We will allocate a certain amount of money every year to highways and Commonwealth road funding, but that is not good enough for the purpose of this model. We are going to take all the Commonwealth Government expenditure—which in 1991 was $1 1/2 billion—and we are going to add to that the $3.2 billion that the States and local governments spend on roads, put it all in one bundle, and say that Dr Hewson and the coalition are going to raise all of that through increased road user charges'. Nothing could be further from the truth.

Even assuming that that is correct, the Treasury then goes on to make an analysis of the increase in costs to industry from having an increase in road user charges of $2,238 per heavy vehicle. Now, this is the really fascinating stuff. It says that the price of dairy products would increase by 0.72 per cent; the price of cereal products would increase by 0.82 per cent; and the price of meat and seafood would also increase by 0.71 per cent because of transport. What the Treasury does not say is that the Government's own increases in road user charges are three to four times the figures used in this model. If the Government goes ahead with its proposed increases in road user charges, the increase in the price of dairy products will not be 0.72 per cent, it will be 2.1 to 2.9 per cent. The increase in cereal products will not be 0.82 per cent, but will be something in the vicinity of 2.4 to 3.2 per cent.

Finally, we can find some truth in the figures the Government has come up with. The only truth in the figures that the Government has come up with is the truth about its shambolical plan to increase road user charges in this nation. Senator Boswell, my good colleague and the National Party Senate leader, and I have been saying for a long time that the proposed road user increases that have been put forward by this Government would destroy industry in regional Australia. It would, in fact, destroy industry in this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why we fought so hard to keep them out.

—As Senator Boswell says, that is why we fought so hard to keep them out. Now, finally, in the Treasury figures we can see the real consequence of increasing road user charges by the amount that the Government wants. Now we can see the truth about what the Government would do to industry in this country.

PARA.TAB: There is another interesting analysis somewhere in these hundreds and hundreds of pages of figures, and that is the increase in costs to individual industries resulting from an increase in registration charges of $2,238 per vehicle per annum. For example, the Government says that there would be an increase of 4.33 per cent in costs for the road transport industry. If that were correct, and we multiplied that by four, the increase in costs to the road transport industry, of the Government's proposal, would be in the vicinity of 16 to 20 per cent per annum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sixteen per cent is what the industry believes.

—Sixteen per cent, as Senator Boswell interjects, is what the industry believes. So the industry is right and Mr Brown, the Minister, is wrong. Surprise, surprise! Every time Mr Brown and the industry have had a dispute, the industry has been right and Mr Brown has been wrong.

PARA.TAB: In attempting to have a go at the coalition, the Government has shot itself in the foot once again. TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join the debate on our response to the ministerial statement of the man who purports to be Treasurer. PARA.TAB: The reason we are having a ministerial statement is that we sought, very properly, to ascertain the documentation on the extent of the work of a party political nature that public servants have been forced to do by the Government. SPEECH.PARA: The corporate role of the portfolio is to advise and assist in the management of the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: So let us have a look at the extent of the errors that Treasury made in its advice to the Government which the Government accepted in its projections for the year 1990-91. Then we will have a look at why we use the actual figures for 1990-91 as distinct from any of the Government's estimates. All Budgets are, are guesses—learned guesses, guesstimates; call them what you will. They are nonetheless estimates and guesstimates. It is not until we get one year's actual figures that we have any hard data to work from.

So let us have look at how Treasury got it wrong in its own government Budget with regard to outlays and revenue for the year 1990-91. It got it wrong for social security and welfare by 3.4 per cent of Budget estimates; in other words, it got it wrong by nearly $1 billion. It got industry development and assistance wrong by an upward estimate of 49 per cent. It failed miserably on assets sales. It got that wrong by 83.8 per cent.

All in all, the Treasury had a total error of 3.3 per cent in the amount of outlays that it thought it would have to make. That is a figure in the vicinity of $3 billion. With regard to the revenue—that is, how much it thought it would collect—it got wrong by 8.1 per cent the amount of PAYE tax it thought it would collect . In other words, it collected in excess of $3 billion less than it thought it would. Other income tax, which largely covers provisional tax, it got wrong by a further 6.8 per cent. The Treasury got company tax wrong; it also got wholesale sales tax wrong by a massive 12.2 per cent. Its total error in the amount of revenue it estimated it would receive was 3.1 per cent. In other words, the error it made is large, comprehensive and shows very simply that it does not meet the criteria set down today by Mr Dawkins that we should accept what Treasury has to say because it gets it accurate.
