The Australian people will not be duped. This pathetic statement and this wonderful set of documents—which I think would almost be worthy of Customs—contain information that is actually quite helpful; but there is information which is designed to snow people; which is simply designed to fudge the issues. When did we get it? At 3 o'clock, just as the thing was brought down.
Senator Bolkus—You should have rung the ABC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we should have rung the ABC. What did it cost to prepare all this? What did it cost all up to pay all those public servants burning the midnight oil to put out the figures to try to put the kybosh on the Fightback package? The days when the Australian people can accept that there remains integrity in the Government are gone.

PARA.TAB: I do not and will not blame the Treasury officials. They have had it put upon them that they must comply with the wishes of the government of the day. It is only a government of the day which has integrity that does not place its public servants in a position where their own integrity is at peril. The Public Service will see that it has been placed in an intolerable position. This statement fails to meet the standards on which it is meant to rise or fall—accountability, impartiality and accuracy. So too does the ABC, which is supposed to be a freestanding organ that presents issues which need to be debated in the community.

The Australian public have been the losers in this unpleasant murky mire of simply unacceptable behaviour. But when the election comes, the people will have the opportunity to make their decision, to make their judgment. And this Government, which simply no longer has any integrity left, will be dispatched to the pages of history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard an interesting debate in which each side has flexed its muscles and said, `Our package is more credible than the other'. That is really the gist of the debate here today.
—It is now for the man in white.

—As Senator Bolkus says, it is now for the man in white. That might not be a bad way of approaching this discussion. I do not think there is any evil in the hearts of the Opposition in bringing back the—
—Not after the last speech?
—Senator Bishop was very pleasant; she was putting the position of the Opposition in the best possible way.
—They don't have hearts.

—I know that Senator Faulkner and Senator Bolkus have nothing but admiration for Senator Bishop and the way she puts her case. The Opposition has really striven, in its own way, to put forward a package which it thinks will solve the problems of Australia. Indeed, as an example, chapter 11 of the Fightback package, which is headed `Assistance for the Family', reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition will substantially reduce the burden which millions of Australian families had to carry under Labor. We will do this primarily through the tax system, through reform of the labour market and where necessary through the social security system. We want to ensure that where additional family assistance is provided through the expenditure system, it goes to those who most need it.
That seems all very good and it is very praiseworthy. I am sure that everybody on the coalition benches believes sincerely in it. Indeed, that is the difficulty—they believe in it.

PARA.TAB: One of the more unhappy phrases contained in that statement is, `We will do this. . . through reform of the labour market'. It seems to me that that is where the two packages—the Fightback package on the one hand and the One Nation package on the other hand—differ most fundamentally. They differ on the issue of the labour market and how people in the work force—or who hope to be in the work force—are to be treated under both systems.
One of the great difficulties with the Fightback package is that the coalition cannot accept that unionists can be decent, honest, hardworking members of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we can.
—Senator Campbell is a man I greatly respect.
—Why?

—Because he tries hard. Honourable senators will see what I mean if they look at what is being said by people who might not be seen as being traditionally attached to the Labor Party. I want to refer to an article in the Weekend Australian which was written by one of the intellectuals of the Australian scene, Mr Santamaria, whom I think Senator Bolkus and Senator Faulkner would concede has not, over the years, been all that inclined to adopt the Labor Party's cause. He has this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: In a period of declining real wages, how far does Dr Hewson propose further to reduce them to enable Australian labour costs to compete with Chinese or Indonesian? And, with one million unemployed, what hope has an ordinary worker of bargaining fairly with the boss without union protection? Defeating communist power in unions and insisting on democratic safeguards in union elections are one thing; destroying unionism itself is another.

PARA.TAB: Senator COONEY—Before the dinner break I was saying that one of the most marked differences between the Fightback package and the One Nation statement is the attitude to labour and the labour market. It is of some concern that the Opposition's Fightback package is such a radical document. We on this side of the chamber sometimes become concerned at the radical nature of the proposals made by the Opposition. I think it is that sort of thing that struck Mr Santamaria when he was moved to make the statement he did, which I quoted before the dinner break.

Mr Santamaria's statement arose out of the traditions from which he came and the philosophy he adopted. They are to be found in a number of papal encyclicals. It is interesting to see what they say about unions and the necessity for them. I do not suggest for one minute that the Opposition should rely on statements or philosophies that have the blessing of papal authority. Nevertheless, I think it is something to take into account, for us on this side of the chamber, when we are looking at what ought to be the appropriate direction for this country to take in the future, what sort of policies it ought to adopt and where it ought to go.

It is my thinking that the people of Australia will be keen to stick to the traditional ways in which we have conducted the affairs of this nation in the past and which, by and large, have served us well, particularly in that dimension of society where the trade unions have played such a great and mighty part. To use a hackneyed phrase, it is more in sorrow than in anger that we on this side of the chamber note what, in the circumstances, can only be called a vicious attack that is to be perpetrated on the union movement through the workings of the Fightback package.
One hundred years ago Pope Leo XIII, in his encyclical Rerum Novarum, talked about the benefit of `helpful organisations'. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The most important of all are Working-men's Unions; for these virtually include all the rest. History attests what excellent results were brought about by the Artificers' Guilds of olden times. They were the means of affording not only many advantages to the workmen, but in no small degree of promoting the advancement of art, as numerous monuments remain to bear witness. Such Unions should be suited to the requirements of this our age—
of course, this was 100 years ago—

an age of wider education, of different habits, and of far more numerous requirements in daily life. It is gratifying to know that there are actually in existence not a few associations of this nature, consisting either of workmen alone, or of workmen and employers together; but it were greatly to be desired that they should become more numerous and more efficient.

I simply point out that this was a very eminent figure of 100 years ago encouraging the increase in strength of the unions, whereas in this Fightback package, this radical document, quite the opposite is proposed. It is a matter of regret that the Fightback package should be so centred upon destroying this great institution of unionism. I think it would be fair to say that Mr John Howard, who is the shadow Minister for industrial relations, does not go as far as his Leader in trying to put down the unions. Nevertheless, the general thrust from the coalition side is to try to break down this great guardian of workers' rights.

PARA.TAB: I come to a work published by the present Pope, an encyclical called Centesimus Annus, which was written on the anniversary of Rerum Novarum. One can see from that that the thinking of the Popes has not changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pope Leo, in particular.
—Yes. As Senator Robert Ray reminds me, it was Pope Leo XIII in the first case and Pope Jean-Paul II in the second case. Pope Jean-Paul II in this encyclical Centesimus Annus had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, society and the State must ensure wage levels adequate for the maintenance of the worker and his family, including a certain amount for savings. This requires a continuous effort to improve workers' training and capability so that their work will be more skilled and productive, as well as careful controls and adequate legislative measures to block shameful forms of exploitation, especially to the disadvantage of the most vulnerable workers, of immigrants and of those on the margins of society. The role of trade unions in negotiating minimum salaries and working conditions is decisive in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he also talked very much about not having collectivist solutions—not too much governmental control. There's a bit in it for both of us.
—Quote your own Pope, Senator.

—Senator Alston shows the difficulty that honourable senators on the other side have. I know that Senator Alston has at times been a radical person who wants to change some of the great institutions upon which this society has so successfully gone forward. He wants now to tear down the institution of unionism. That is what I am talking about; I am not talking about collectivism. All I am saying is that over 100 years ago Pope Leo XIII praised unionism and said that it must increase and flourish; and now, 100 years later, his successor Jean-Paul II also says just that. Senator Alston was not in here before dinner, but a person who is very much imbued with this tradition, Mr Santamaria—who, as I said before, could hardly be labelled as a friend of the Party to which I so proudly belong—said that the actions of Senator Alston's Party and Dr Hewson in particular give him great concern. Had Senator Alston been here he would have heard me quote Mr Santamaria. We on this side, who are perhaps a little slower than honourable senators opposite to tear down these great institutions, feel some concern.
—Like the monarchy.
—Yes. We do not want to tear down the monarchy; that has never been the proposition. I quote this last piece from John Paul II:

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, `humane' working hours and adequate free-time need to be guaranteed, as well as the right to express one's own personality at the work-place without suffering any affront to one's conscience or personal dignity. This is the place to mention once more the role of trade unions, not only in negotiating contracts, but also as `places' where workers can express themselves. They serve the development of an authentic culture of work and help workers to share in a fully human way in the life of their place of employment.
There is nothing in those two passages that talks about wages being tied to productivity and workers being in some way machines that should be treated like any other machine.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did St Paul have to say about it?

—As Senator Parer knows, St Paul said that great respect must be paid to the dignity of man. Not only religious people but also judges of the High Court have traditionally supported the existence of unions. As Senator Alston would know, their Honours Mr Justice Isaacs and Mr Justice Rich in the well known case of the Federated Municipal and Shire Council Employees Union of Australia v. the Melbourne Corporation had this to say around 1918 or 1919 when talking about the Industrial Revolution:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . "industrial revolution" for a long time—
I will leave out a reference and continue from where the sentence makes sense—
made the workman's labour a mere marketable commodity to be bought at the lowest price that individual competition between workers would permit.

That is the difficulty that those opposite face. They treat men's and women's labour as a mere marketable commodity, which it was never meant to be, to be bought and sold at the lowest price that individual competition between workers would permit. Their Honours go on to say:

The degradation and suffering that ensued, the revolt against the system, the repression of illegal acts, the amelioration of the law, the organisation of labour, the gradual recognition of collective bargaining, the introduction of private conciliation and arbitration as well as of industrial laws securing better conditions for workers, are all well-known historical facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they do not endorse compulsory unionism.

—Senator Alston talks about compulsory unionism but, as has been said in the encyclicals, it is not just a matter of existing as individuals. As we live in a society, we are obliged not only to take from society but also to give to society and to organisations.
—Voluntarily, though. They were into freedom of choice.

—A lot of freedom of choice has been denied Senator Alston. However, I simply say that people cannot so act as to jeopardise the working conditions and the wages of a group of people, and it is wrong that they should do so. All I say to those opposite is this: if they were not so locked in ideologically to their anti-unionism, a lot more could be made of the coalition's package than is presently the case.

PARA.TAB: The difficulty with the Opposition's present proposition is that it denies people the ability to get better wages and conditions through their organisations. That is the practical effect of it all and that is the sort of thing the High Court judges were talking about. The Opposition is saying that the state will in some way adjust things. It will take money from people through the goods and services tax at 15 per cent, or whatever it is, and it will give it back to them. That is not encouraging individualism; that is encouraging a mendicant attitude. What it is doing is collecting and then giving back as a matter of grace.

TALK.START.PARA: —As any tax system does—but we give you back more.

—I am not going to go into the argument that Senator Alston's daddy is bigger than mine. That is what this argument is all about, and that is why we have this argument as to where people benefit most financially.

PARA.TAB: In the debate that has taken place here today those opposite have been saying that their proposition is better because it puts more money into people's pockets, and we have been saying that ours does and the Opposition's does not. That is why, to an extent, I have ignored that point and gone on to what I say is the fundamental principle in this issue, which is labour market policies. That is where the propositions that those opposite put forward are so vulnerable.

I think Mr John Howard, with respect to him, sees that distinction. But his Leader does not see it, and the general culture within the coalition parties at the moment does not see that. That is where the package is very dangerous and that is where it becomes a problem for working men and women with families. They will be very vulnerable, naked, left without any effective protection under the system of labour market regulations proposed by those opposite.

That is what has happened in New Zealand. If I could return to people of religious bent, the bishops of New Zealand have talked about the employment contracts legislation in New Zealand. I am not saying that the legislation the coalition will bring in on labour market reform, so-called, will be the same, but the general thrust will be. This is what the bishops in New Zealand had to say about the legislation:

SPEECH.PARA: It involves ethics and morality. The question must be asked what the new legislation does to people and society, to human dignity and the common good. As Bishops of New Zealand—
and they are writing this letter to the people of New Zealand—

we must speak against this proposed legislation as its underlying ideology is contrary to the social doctrines of the Church. Pope Paul VI teaches that, "All social action involves a doctrine. The Christian cannot admit that which is based upon a materialistic and atheistic philosophy". The underlying ideology of the new industrial legislation is unacceptable for two reasons: firstly, because it emphasises free choice—
those opposite disagree with this, but this is what the bishops say—

without balancing this concept with concern for the common, that is the public, good; and secondly because it emphasises the rights of the individual without their accompanying duty to act in solidarity and without giving any corresponding rights to the group.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just sophistry. They're really against freedom of choice.
—This is not me speaking; this is the bishops of New Zealand, in the light of this great tradition that the Catholic Church has passed down.
—They got it wrong.

—Those opposite disagree with that. I accept that they reject that philosophy. I simply say that people on this side of the chamber see great merit in this concept. When those opposite go in for what I think are not only radical but almost revolutionary actions in the labour market, it is of some concern to the more sober people on this side. That is all I am saying. That is where the big philosophical difference lies. We are concerned for people as part of a group; those opposite are concerned for the individual—the Wild West man, the cowboy. I do not think that is reasonable, but it is understandable. However, we say something different. The difficulty with the Opposition's proposition is that unionists become scapegoats.
—That is how you want to see it portrayed.
—Again, I will not quote myself; I will quote an article from the Australian Financial Review of Monday, 24 February 1992, which talks about how a meat union won friends.
—Who is it?
—It talks about a man in Melbourne known as Mr Wally Curran. It has this to say about him:

SPEECH.PARA: Not so long ago, the union and its fiery secretary, Mr Wally Curran, were blamed for virtually all the industry's numerous problems—the tens of thousands of man-days lost each year to industrial action, the closure of more than half the State's export abattoirs and the alleged transfer interstate of thousands of head of livestock for processing.

PARA.TAB: Farmer and employer groups claimed that the union's "intransigence" was destroying the $1 billion local processing industry.
More recently, however, attention has swung back to the accusers.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not continue reading the article. It was published on page 7 of the Australian Financial Review of Monday, 24 February 1992. It goes on to show that all sorts of factors have brought on the problems in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: What concerns me—and I use the situation of Mr Curran as an example—is the approach that the Opposition takes generally to unions and unionists; namely that they are to be the scapegoats for all the problems in the world. That just ignores the facts. All I want members of the Opposition to do is to look at the facts of these situations and examine them in a rational way; not to be carried away with ideology and every new fad that comes their way, but to try to look at the evidence that is presented.

I will close on this note: I think that the Fightback package, as I said at the start, is motivated by nothing but the finest of aspirations, that is, to do something for the people of Australia. The people who have put it forward are genuine in their belief that it will do good; indeed a lot of good. They genuinely believe that this package will reform Australia and make things better. That is the problem—they believe in a false god; they believe in a poisoned chalice.

It would be almost better if it was put forward in some sort of cynical fashion, which it is not, because then at least some of the solutions it suggests could be adjusted in a realistic manner. But the Opposition is not going to do that. It is going to drive Australia into all sorts of problems because it believes so deeply in this package. All I have tried to do is illustrate the danger of that in terms of the actions that the Opposition will take in the labour market. They are going to be just awful.

I invite the Opposition to look at the One Nation document, the answer to that package, and see the good things that are in it—and they are many. In particular, the document puts forward a labour market program which will overcome the difficulties that the Fightback package, in a way unwittingly, would bring about in the sort of society we want to have in this country. By and large, we have been a community, particularly over the last 10 years, that has acted together. If these new and very worrying changes proposed within the Fightback package were to be brought in, that very fragile—and it is fragile—consensus that has brought success, and will bring even greater success in the future if it is maintained, will be fragmented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would find Senator Cooney's moral suasion rather more convincing if the facts did not show that, over the period since 1983, there has been quite a massive shift of wealth from the less well off to the more well off in our community; and if, for argument's sake, the percentage of government expenditure that went into the social welfare area or the education of our young was anywhere near the OECD average or, indeed, anywhere near the average percentage of some of the other countries with which we like to compare ourselves.

PARA.TAB: The facts are that, since the advent of the Labor Government, of course, we have seen an emphasis on a market driven economic system. The basis of that is the belief that what the market delivers is both good and inevitable and, fundamentally, underneath the operation of the market is the moral view that greed is good. That goes right back to Adam Smith and the invisible hand and the belief that, through the operation of competitive greed, the common good would be served. Of course, what we have with the Opposition's Fightback package is not `greed is good' but rather `more greed is better' because it will simply drive the same system harder and further and with an even more socially disruptive impact on the Australian community.

The purpose of my brief remarks tonight is to pick up on the question which I asked Senator Button today and make a point about the computer models on which much, although not all, of the debate in recent days has been based, and point to the total inadequacy of those models and some of the assumptions which are fed into them.

It seems to me that although the expression `garbage in, garbage out' has been around for perhaps 15 years, we find that in this chamber at least and in many of the comments which are made outside this chamber by members of the chamber and, indeed, by many, although not all, of the economic commentators, there seems to be a too ready acceptance that what comes out of a computer is factual and reliable and can be used as the basis of argument as to whose package is the best or whose package will deliver a better result for the economy.

Such is not the case. The assumptions which are fed into these computer models are, even in terms of commonsense, manifestly stupid. To argue whether the Murphy model—on which the Fightback package is substantially based and on which the Government has based part of its attempt to discredit the Fightback package—will produce 4 per cent, 3 per cent or 2 1/2 per cent inflation so many years out into the future, is simply waving useless words in the air when the assumptions on which the models are based, as I will show, are demonstrably so completely without any foundation at all.

Several of the economic journalists who have picked up the absence of substance in the computer models are Ken Davidson writing in the Age and Peter Hartcher writing in the Sydney Morning Herald. It is interesting that Ken Davidson writing in the Age specifically points to the Murphy model and says:

SPEECH.PARA: The model's architect, Dr Cris Murphy, describes it as short-run Keynesian and long run neo-classical. This means that in the short run, a lift in Government spending can lead to an overall rise in employment and output. But, because in the long run, output is determined by the productivity of the `supply side' of the economy and because general Government spending, even on capital goods, has no impact on productivity,—
and note that point—
it can have no net positive impact on output and employment because it `crowds out' an equivalent level of productive private spending.

So when we turn to the Murphy model—and I have a copy of a print out of its results here in front of me—we find just that: a basic assumption in this model that government spending, irrespective of how it is spent, will make no long run difference to the overall economic productivity of the country.As I say, that is manifestly stupid and we can go through table after table.

PARA.TAB: I will list a few of the items: general consumption, general government consumption, private dwelling investment, private non-dwelling construction investment, private equipment investment, real estate transfer expenses, public enterprise fixed investment, general government fixed investment, private non-farm inventory investment, farm and public authority inventory investment, statistical discrepancy, gross national expenditure, exports of goods and services, imports of goods and services, gross domestic product, public final demand, domestic final demand, private business fixed investment, nominal gross domestic product, gross domestic product deflator and so it goes on.

There is page after page of indicators all set at zero because the assumption is that, however government spends its money, it will make no difference whatsoever in the long run to any of those indicators. In other words, if the Government—which it evidently is minded to do—takes all its money and throws it into the swamp at Gillman, the MFP site, and wastes it totally; or, alternatively, if it spends that money on a better rail system for Australia to improve the efficiency of our rail transport; or if, for instance, it spends that money on a better educational system; the model on which most of the debate is based makes the assumption that there would be no difference whatsoever to any of the economic indicators no matter which of those choices was made.

Interestingly, when I asked the question of Senator Button today, not only did he not know that that was an assumption which was built into the computer models and many of the other computer models but also from the loud guffaws that I heard on both sides of this chamber I could only presume that most people in this chamber did not know that that assumption is built into the computer models.

Not surprisingly, if one built into the model at the beginning that, irrespective of how government spends its money, it can make no difference to the economic productivity of a country, one will conclude that it is a good idea to cut down on government expenditure. In other words, one will draw the conclusion that there is a direct relationship with the assumption made on the input. As I said at the beginning: garbage in, garbage out.

Exactly the same sorts of things apply to the extended model which was used by the Government in its econometric analysis. Indeed, Peter Hartcher in his article in the Sydney Morning Herald a few days ago made a very telling comment when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If economics is the dismal science, then econometrics is the faintly absurd science. . .
I think it is the exceedingly absurd science. Anything that claims to be science that makes those sorts of assumptions clearly is not science at all. The article continues:
. . . where the unknowable course of our economic future is purportedly rendered knowable in fine and precise detail—

making the sorts of assumptions to which I have just alluded. He also—and this is very relevant to the Fightback package—made a very telling point against the Fightback package and against the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, because he said;
And yet Fightback and its promotional literature offers it—
that is Fightback!—

as a promise. If there was a moment, a threshold in Dr Hewson's progress in Parliament, when he ceased being a professor and became a politician, it was this promise. It took him out of the realm of the man who was rigorously, sometimes painfully, honest, into the realm of the professional, full-blooded politician.
He goes on to say:
Paul Keating made that transition long ago.

It is a great pity that there is not a little more rigour in this place when it comes to debate. If there were, that rigour would indicate that we should shift the argument entirely away from these econometric models which are so deeply flawed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In other words, you're the sole possessor of virtues and political debate. Is that what you are saying?
—That interjection is interesting. It indicates that the honourable senator does not particularly like the facts to which I am pointing but, rather, chooses to attack me as an individual.
—No, I am asking what the basis of your proposition is.
—You might be smarter than the rest of us, but give us some credit.
—I was quoting Peter Hartcher in the Sydney Morning Herald.
—But your proposition is that everyone else is self-interested and being purely political when indeed you are above all that: you are an honourable man, an objective advocate—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! I think on the whole Senator Coulter can make his own speech at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am making the simple point that it is demonstrably the case that the computer models, on which much of the Opposition's case is built and on which much of the Government's criticism and its own case is built, are demonstrably wrong because they make assumptions which are demonstrably stupid. It is a very simple argument.

PARA.TAB: I am making the point, which should have been demonstrated to everybody's satisfaction today, that Senator Button when he was asked a question did not know that that assumption was built into the computer models. If some honourable senators do not like the evidence of their own ears, then it is a great pity.

We in the Democrats—and I am now making a political point—believe that the argument should be shifted away from these econometric models and more to the social consequences of the way in which we derive our government revenue and the way in which we spend that. We believe that there are ways—I think Senator Kernot pointed to this today—in which we can direct government expenditure which will significantly make a difference to the economy of this country, quite contrary to the models. We believe that the government expenditure directed in those ways which meet the criteria of sustainability, of providing employment and of addressing the problem of foreign indebtedness can be brought together; that those three criteria are not mutually inconsistent.

If government were to have some vision, or if the Opposition were to have some vision, on how it might direct government expenditure, those things could be done; we could indeed develop not only one nation but one nation which could lead the world to a much more sustainable, human and humane future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak on this ministerial statement because there have been many speakers, but one cannot sit here and let the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Coulter, get away with what he said. When I was preparing some other work tonight in my office I heard Senator Coulter say that both the Government and the Opposition believe that greed is good. He went on to say that, as far as the Opposition is concerned, more greed is better. What an extraordinary statement for the leader of a party to make in here.

PARA.TAB: I ask Senator Coulter and the Democrats: what is wrong with either the Opposition or the Government trying to put a proposal before the Australian public that endeavours to make Australia more competitive, to give people incentives to try to do something about the problems with our current account, our structural problems with unemployment and a range of other things that need addressing in Australia right now, including the level to which our foreign debt has blown out and its servicing costs? Senator Coulter said that if one feeds garbage in one gets garbage out. I found it extraordinary that we could not have had a better contribution from the Leader of the Democrats tonight on this debate.

I will not go over the ground that my colleagues went over other than to say a couple of things about the Treasury analysis that we have had put before us. That analysis is flawed in a number of areas, especially in two of its assumptions: firstly, inflation; and, secondly, transport costs. This will come out clearly in the debate over the next week or so and will demonstrate how clearly the analysis is flawed. There is also a flaw in the One Nation statement on industrial relations. It was remarkable to note the shift in position from the statement that was brought down by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, in October compared with what we now see in the One Nation document.

I also want to defend our Leader, Dr John Hewson. There would be very few people, other than possibly Senator Coulter, who would even remotely suggest that Dr John Hewson tried to con the Australian people or play a political trick on them. One thing that he has endeavoured to do in this debate is to get the issues out on the table: the concerns that all Australians have in terms of unemployment, our ability to meet our foreign debt, our current account problems and all the other problems that we have in Australia today.

Peter Hartcher has been quoted tonight. I do not know who Peter Hartcher is, but if Senator Coulter is quoting him when he suggests that all of a sudden John Hewson has changed his spots and is not endeavouring to put to the Australian public a reasonable, proper, well researched proposition leading up to the next election, then all I can say is that he is talking sheer nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hartcher is the one who deliberately misrepresented the Murphy model. Murphy had to put out a press release condemning him. In quoting him, Senator Coulter ought to be ashamed of himself.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a total misrepresentation of the position of Dr John Hewson. As Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Coulter should hang his head in shame for what he has just done. This has contributed absolutely nothing to the debate.

PARA.TAB: I will leave my comments at that. As I said when I started, I did not intend to speak on this matter, but I could not let those remarks by the Leader of the Democrats go by without making some comment myself. I totally reject the concept that was put before us at the beginning of Senator Coulter's speech. I certainly support the endeavours of the Opposition to make Australian competitive, to make it a fairer place, and to give incentive back to people in order to restore their pride.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Higher Education Funding for the 1992-94 Triennium

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak for a few minutes on this report of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, entitled Higher Education Funding for the 1992-94 Triennium. In it there is a great deal of extremely valuable information for anyone who is interested in knowing the direction of Australian higher education. However, as I looked through it I did notice something missing from its statement about consultation and its indication of the community activities that have occurred as far as the Department is concerned. The one thing that is missing is the Department's reaction to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, which I chair, and to which a number of members in this chamber belong. I just want to put on record tonight that that omission—and I am sure that it is not deliberate; it is probably just an oversight—of the important work that has been done by the Committee is something that ought to be set to rights.

PARA.TAB: The one thing that did come out of our report, and that was taken up by the main players in the game, especially the universities, was a symposium which was organised in conjunction with our Committee, and which was held here in Parliament House in the last few weeks of December last year. That symposium was an extremely valuable event to the extent that the criticisms we made in our report about the quality of teaching in higher education institutions had obviously been taken to heart by the academic community.

Despite our criticisms, representatives from, I think, every higher education institution in the country were prepared to join us to discuss where they were going and the problems that they were facing in terms of improving the quality of teaching. We also discussed ways of improving their techniques—for example, the dissemination of examples of best practice—and of looking at the issues that face them in terms of industrial relations.

I, for one—and I am sure all members of the Committee felt the same way—was very impressed with the way these representatives approached this whole issue. They were honest and frank about the weaknesses of teaching in the higher education system. I believe that most of them went away from that symposium with a better sense of where they were going and a better sense of the problems that currently beset them. In a sense they also overcame a certain degree of `whinginess', which occasionally creeps into education and substitutes for action and deep thought in terms of setting directions for the future.

It was very pleasing indeed to see that not only was the academic community—which has been criticised by us—prepared to join with us for a positive purpose but the Government was prepared to work with us as well. Indeed, the opening by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, gave us an indication that the Government was going to be part of this process.
I just wanted to put that on record at this stage, to indicate that Senate reports, provided they are accurate, provided they are thought out, and—

TALK.START.PARA: —Bipartisan—
—And provided they are bipartisan, as Senator Patterson said—
—Mr Dawkins heaped enormous criticism on that report.
—Let bygones be bygones.
—If you dish it out, you have to be able to cop it back.

—Senator Ray is absolutely correct. If a committee is criticised by a Minister in the heat of the moment, or whatever, and we have dished out criticism in return, then it does not worry me in the least. In fact, in this instance, it put the report of the issues on the front page. If nothing else, at least it made the universities examine their procedures and I think that contributed to the positive discussions that we had in December.

PARA.TAB: Before I resume my seat, I must say that I have been looking at the article in the Examiner—and I wish Senator Baume were here—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—I am pleased to have the opportunity of speaking to this report, Higher Education Funding for the 1992-94 Triennium. In doing so, I point out that in Australia's current economic climate, pressures on higher education are likely to increase. Indeed, on page 13 of this report, it is noted that demand from school leavers will increase next year and there will be reduced intakes in higher education due to institutions adjusting for over-enrolment in 1991.

PARA.TAB: The report goes on to note that the 1991 cohort of year 12 students—which is significantly larger than the previous year's—will be particularly affected by the cut-back in intakes. State governments have also expressed their concern about the lack of opportunity for this year's cohort of school-leavers.

Lack of opportunity in education is something that I and a number of my colleagues are constantly hearing about from our constituents but, sadly, it is not the lack of opportunity for higher education. It is far more serious. It is the lack of opportunity to even finish school. We talk a lot about being the clever country. I guess it is a noble objective and one we would all like to see achieved, but it seems to me that there is clearly an inequity in the availability of education. If one lives in Sydney or any of the towns scattered around the eastern seaboard of Australia, one can be the richest person in the world and one's child can walk down the street to high school, for no real charge. It is virtually free education.

If one happens to live in remote Australia—in western Queensland, parts of New South Wales or Western Australia—one cannot do that. In many cases a very high cost is involved in sending children to school. In the name of equity it does not matter how rich we are, we should have that ability to send our children to school at a reasonable, comparative cost and that ability is just not there. Australia's farming community has the lowest level of formal educational achievement among Western industrialised countries. Obviously this is a cause for great concerns.

Statistics compiled by the Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture show that less than 25 per cent of the Australian farm work force has secondary education above grade 10. This contrasts with more than 50 per cent in New Zealand, North America and Western Europe, and upwards of 90 per cent in Scandinavian countries. This worries me enormously. Australian rural communities, and farmers in particular, have had an excellent record for productivity improvement in Australia in the past. They have far outstripped all other sectors of the economy. But one of the things that will increasingly hold them back in the future is a lack of preparation at an education level to enable them to meet the challenges and grasp the opportunities of the future.

Studies in Australia and the United States have shown that higher levels of education and training significantly improve farm productivity. That is important not only for the farmers involved in these tight times, but also for Australia, which is desperately in need of export improvement and enhancement. I think, too, there is a problem with our need to keep young people on the land. That problem is directly related to being able to better equip them to cope with the challenges that confront them. It also arises from having few education opportunities.

With economic conditions such as we are now facing, in many cases it is the education of rural children that is suffering. Many on the Government side are ideologically opposed to private boarding schools, but for students in isolated areas of Australia it is their only access to high school education. This fact is recognised by the Government through the payment of an isolated children's allowance. As of January this year, each child who is forced to leave home and study because of isolation and living in remote Australia receives a non-means tested portion of $2,500 to board at a hostel or school. Yet the average cost Australia-wide is estimated at $4,900. So one does not have to be a mathematical genius to calculate that there is a shortfall that parents have to pay.

These costs are horrendous, especially when parents have two, three or four children away at school. I have had a lot of contact with the Isolated Children's and Parents Association about the crisis being faced by farming families in trying to educate their children. I would like to congratulate the ICPA on the work it is doing to improve access to education for students in the isolated areas of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks on the DEET report entitled Higher Education Funding for the 1992-94 Triennium. The report outlines funding decisions for this period and supposedly builds on the policies and achievements of the Dawkins 1988 White Paper Higher Education: A Policy Discussion and follows on from the policies outlined in Higher Education: Quality and Diversity in the 1990s.

PARA.TAB: The report labels the 1990s `a period of consolidation' during which we have seen significant changes to the higher education system, the effects of which we are now experiencing. The destruction of the binary divide and the creation of the unified national system have reduced the number of institutions from 76 to 40. The report cites this as a positive step, despite emerging criticisms from academics and students.

The year 1992 will provide us with the opportunity to investigate the academic and economic impact of the merger process and to assess the future viability of the unified national system while turning our attention to those campuses that have resisted efforts to merge. The report outlines the impact of over-enrolments on 1992 intakes, believing that:

SPEECH.PARA: The pressures on higher education are likely to increase.

Where institutions exceeded commencing load targets in 1991, they are now reducing the number of offers for 1992. This has resulted in extraordinary levels of unmet demand, with over 50,000 students nationally missing out on university places this year.

PARA.TAB: Over-enrolments averaging 7 per cent—or 23,000 students—and massive levels of overcrowding have had detrimental effects on the standard of our education system, as admitted in the National Board of Employment Education and Training's advice on planning for the 1992-94 triennium. The Board states that reports from institutions indicated that overcrowding was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . .sufficiently severe as to be seen as detrimental to a proper learning environment.

These effects include greatly increased lecture, tutorial and laboratory sizes, declining teaching standards and adverse effects on staff-student contact and research. The injection of nearly $300m in capital funding is a welcome measure, but will occur too late to alleviate many of the overcrowding problems of 1991-92 and is of little consolation to students in the system coping with crowded tutorials and decaying buildings.

PARA.TAB: The decision by the Government to incorporate capital funding into operating grants from 1994 has disadvantages for specific institutions. Therefore, it is important that consultation takes place with these institutions. We look forward to the outcome of this process in a supplementary funding report.

This report notes that by 1994 the Government will have provided 85,000 new places in higher education over the decade. Increasing access to the higher education system is a commendable objective. However, these extra places have not been matched with additional funding for staffing, infrastructure and capital works. As a percentage of GDP, government spending on higher education has decreased from 1.03 per cent in 1983 to 0.92 per cent in 1991-92.

The report points out that students will be paying $2,250 per year in the higher education contribution scheme in 1992. Cynical hikes in HECS have occurred twice above the CPI since its introduction, and this figure is climbing steadily and dangerously towards full cost fees.

The Government's purported commitment to access and equity measures is duplicitous when students are forced to pay a rising HECS charge. The $3.9m allocation for equity programs in 1992 and the increase in Aboriginal support funds by 1993 are progressive steps towards encouraging participation by traditionally disadvantaged groups. The Government's recognition that HECS exemption scholarships are an important means of promoting Australia's research effort is a concession that HECS is a financial barrier to higher education for many students, especially post-graduate students.

This report looks into the 1990s and the outcomes of the Dawkins-led reforms. The legacy is one of declining funding for infrastructure, staffing and capital. It has bequeathed to us forcibly amalgamated institutions which have been pressured to over-enrol as many students as possible in order to get the funding on which they depend. The report acknowledges the importance of a balance between post-school education and training, especially if we are to meet the goals outlined in the Finn review. However, pressing concerns such as overcrowding, the effects of amalgamations, unmet demand and financial barriers to participation still remain and must be resolved if we are to become the clever and capable country.

—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 19 of 1991-92, project audits, Department of Social Security—operational performance monitoring, sickness benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australia National Audit Office's report No. 19 relates to the Department of Social Security, operational performance security and sickness benefit. This is yet another indictment of the running of the Department of Social Security. It also counteracts the claim that Senator Richardson made when he was Minister for Social Security—before he did the deal with Mr Keating for his job in communications—that Social Security had no fat left on it for trimming. He was definitely wrong. Auditor-General's report after Auditor-General's report has shown that—and Auditor-General's report No. 19 is no exception. Under the heading `Key Findings', the report states:

Both departmental studies and previous ANAO audits have indicated that improvements are needed. For example, only some 40% of regional offices were complying with the Department's quality assurance procedures; and when a performance accountability improvement reporting system was introduced, two area offices decided not to follow through with its implementation.

In speaking to this part of the Auditor-General's report, I wish to refer to the breakdown in operational performance monitoring that occurred last month. To talk about the breakdown of operational performance monitoring may seem irrelevant but was actually very relevant to the 6,000 people whose names, addresses and other details appeared on the backs of letters that were sent to 6,000 other people. Performance monitoring is very important when it comes to issues such as the sending out of letters and other very delicate details and issues that Social Security handles.

PARA.TAB: Six thousand letters were sent to beneficiaries containing the financial details of other people. The error occurred in Sydney during a mail out of those 6,000 letters advising changes in pensions and family allowance entitlements throughout New South Wales. In a letter sent to backbenchers late last month, the Minister for Social Security, Dr Blewett, admitted:

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the personal information included on the back of this advice was not that of the person to whom the advice was sent. This information included details of the financial institution account to which the pension or family allowance is paid, together with, in some instances, figures on the personal income and assets against which the person's entitlement should be assessed.

I suppose it does not matter all that much to Dr Blewett. As far as he is concerned, as a socialist, the interests of the community should come before individual rights. He is on the record as saying:
We shouldn't get too hung up as socialists on privacy, because privacy in many ways is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property.

It fills me with cheer to know that the current Minister for Social Security has that attitude about privacy. I suppose it would not worry him too much, but he had to put out a letter to make it look as though he really cared about the issue of privacy. A departmental spokesman pointed out to the media:
The bungle occurred after a laser printer malfunctioned.

I cannot believe how often we are told in Estimates `Oh, Senator, it was a computer error' as if that is an excuse. I have said time and again in this chamber that a computer error is not an excuse. We find out in Estimates that letters are mailed out to pensioners telling them that they have not answered correspondence which they have never had. They are scared by the fact that they have received a second letter telling them that they have not complied with some instruction from the Department when in fact they never received the first letter. What do the bureaucrats from the Department say to me in Estimates? They say, `Oh, Senator, it was a computer error'. That is no excuse.

PARA.TAB: We must have checks in place; there must be performance monitoring which ensures that that error does not occur. The Department can stand here and tell me that it sends out so many millions of letters a year. We cannot let computers dominate us. I have said a number of times in this chamber that one of the major issues in the next decade will be that of information storage and retrieval. It is an issue that all of us ought to address. I do not want the next generation to turn around and say, `Why didn't you do something about it?'. Doing something about it is not accepting that computer error is an excuse. The departmental spokesman said:

SPEECH.PARA: The bungle occurred after a laser printer malfunctioned. The print run was shifted to another printer—
I presume there was a human being there who shifted it—
and the new material was printed on the backs of the documents. The Department's system of sampling checks then broke down as well.

The performance monitoring should be such that that should not happen. The victims of this breakdown were rightly angry. One has already indicated that she will be taking legal action against the Department. Their anger is even more understandable when it is recognised that such errors are not new.

PARA.TAB: In April last year the same problem occurred in Perth with some 660 people affected. In April there was a similar error. Why was a better performance monitoring check not put in place then? The Department knew that this sort of thing could happen. After the latest blunder the Privacy Commissioner, Mr O'Connor, claimed that he had understood the error was rectified after the incident in Perth a year ago. A departmental officer stated last month:

SPEECH.PARA: When it happened in Perth we couldn't pin down what caused it, but we put in a lot of new procedures to stop it happening again.

But it did happen again. In July last year the then Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson—before he did his deal and got his job in communications, the little job he wanted before he leaves—wrote to one of the Perth victims stating that the Department had introduced tighter controls to guard against the problem happening again. He said:
I am most concerned about errors of this nature and am satisfied that the Department acted quickly to rectify the problem.

We now find that the very same problem also occurred in Melbourne only a week before the revelation that it had occurred in Sydney. The bungle had occurred in Melbourne and Perth and nothing had been done apparently to rectify the problem. It is pertinent that in the key findings of the audit report the Audit Office has recommended that:
. staff at all levels need to understand clearly the objectives of operational performance monitoring, and have a greater commitment to undertaking it.

The staff need to be aware that the information they are dealing with is very personal. They cannot afford to make an error; they cannot afford to accept that the computer broke down. They must apply all the principles of monitoring that are in place and maybe even be encouraged to make suggestions about what else could happen to ensure that this does not happen. They should have a sense of corporate responsibility for maintaining that data so that it does not escape in the way it has and so that people's personal information does not appear on the back of letters going to other people.

PARA.TAB: The Department and the Privacy Commissioner have initiated inquiries into this blunder and I eagerly await the expeditious conclusion of these inquiries and the public airing of their findings. This bungle could have been avoided. As I said, it resulted from operational staff not checking computer printed mail closely enough following a computer breakdown. It is a simple enough task to install an automatic checking mechanism after such a breakdown or to direct computer operating staff to undertake a manual check. Minister Neil Blewett stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Such a disclosure is a serious breach of privacy, and I have instructed the Department to cooperate fully with the Privacy Commissioner with any inquiries he may initiate.

I believe that this bungle is more than a serious breach of privacy; it is a serious breach of the Privacy Act. Information privacy principle four, relating to the storage and security of personal information, states:
A record keeper who has possession or control of a record that contains personal information shall ensure:

(a)That the record is protected, by such security safeguards as it is reasonable in these circumstances to take, against loss, against unauthorised access, use, modification or disclosure, and against other misuse, and

(b)That if it is necessary for the record to be given to a person in connection with the provision of a service to the record-keeper, everything reasonably within the power of the record-keeper is done to prevent unauthorised use or disclosure of information contained in the record.

I believe that in this case it is very doubtful whether the Department of Social Security has ensured that there are reasonable security safeguards in the circumstances to protect these records against unauthorised disclosure. As such, it is quite possible that the victims of this bungle may be able to claim compensation under the Privacy Act. As the shadow Minister, Senator Alston, pointed out in his news release of 7 February:

After investigating a complaint, Section 52(1)(iii) of the Privacy Act 1988 empowers the Privacy Commissioner to `find the complaint substantiated and to make a determination that includes. . . a declaration that the complainant is entitled to a specified amount by way of compensation to individuals for any loss or damage suffered. . .
Minister Blewett claimed on television:
I think it is most inappropriate that we should provide taxpayers' money as some kind of compensation in this situation.

That not only shows Minister Blewett's ignorance of the Privacy Act; it also demonstrates his attitude towards privacy—a bourgeois concept, as he called it. In his letter to backbenchers, Minister Blewett stated:
The Department is writing to all the people affected by this incident, firstly to apologise for their error and secondly to seek urgent return of the incorrect advices.

I have not seen a copy of this letter being sent to these people. However, I have tonight asked for a copy of the text of the letter by way of a question upon notice. I would almost lay odds on that the Department of Social Security has seen fit to inform the victims of this bungle about information privacy principle four and section 52(1)(iii) of the Privacy Act.

PARA.TAB: The next revelation in this Auditor-General's report relates to the administration of sickness benefits. It is enlightening to read. The Audit Office's findings in relation to the administration of sickness benefits amount to an overwhelming endorsement of the decision in Fightback! to tighten the administration of this benefit. As well, it is a major rebuff for the Department of Finance, which underestimated the savings to be derived from such a measure. In light of the audit report, it is likely that the savings the coalition estimates will be derived from tightening the administration of sickness allowance may be very conservative indeed. In the key findings of the audit report it states:

SPEECH.PARA: An audit of sickness benefit indicated that legislative and procedural requirements had not been followed adequately in that:
1. a significant proportion of clients in receipt of sickness benefit did not satisfy the legislative requirements of the Social Security Act—
that is astounding—

and/or were not processed in accordance with departmental instructions and procedures—for example, DSS files indicated that medical eligibility was in doubt in 22 per cent of new claim cases and 32 per cent—
nearly a third—
of continuation cases—
this is another interesting fact—
and an Audit Office sample showed that up to 40 per cent of clients had been declared medically fit for light or other work but were still on benefit contrary to departmental instructions.

No more fat left in the system! Branded, we were, by Senator Richardson as the people who were going to take money from the lame, the sick and the poor. That is what he said. He cast Senator Alston as the wicked person who was going to come and take all these benefits away. Yet here is the Auditor-General telling us that a large number, a significant proportion, of clients did not satisfy the legislative requirements of the Social Security Act, and that 40 per cent of them had been declared medically fit for light or other work but were still on benefit contrary to departmental instructions. The Auditor-General's report goes on:

2. reviews conducted by the Department to reassess continuing entitlement were not being processed adequately, and many were ineffectual in result through failure to act on treating doctors' reports, delays in processing review forms, and overlooking cases of possible overpayment.

No more fat in the system! So lean we could not extract anything more out of it, yet the report talks of `overlooking cases of possible overpayment'. It was also found that, of an audit sample of sickness benefit recipients who had been on benefit for 24 months, none had been selected for review despite the fact that review initiatives introduced by the Department in December 1989 called for such reviews. It makes interesting reading. In our Fightback! document the coalition states:

. . . will ensure that only those genuinely sick and unable to work will receive this benefit. We will introduce more stringent and frequent medical examinations. The Coalition will require certificates from two independent medical practitioners to be provided whereas in the present just one medical certificate is required to receive sickness allowance.

This is not to try to take away sickness benefits from those who really need them. The more that this is targeted to those in genuine need, the more money, the more cake there will be to give to those people who genuinely need it. This report shows very clearly that there is still a huge amount of slop in the system. In addition, a coalition government will make the three-monthly medical review mandatory, while at six months DSS will have the discretion to direct recipients to be reviewed by a Commonwealth medical officer. The estimated net savings from this tightened administration, as well as extending the waiting period for sickness allowance to three weeks, will be $52.7m.

PARA.TAB: Backing up the coalition's call for tighter administration of medical evidence provided in relation to claims for sickness allowance, the Audit Office recommends:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . medical practitioners and hospitals be encouraged more firmly to adopt the standard medical certificate and to ensure that the required information be provided in all cases.
In accordance with the coalition's call for improved medical review procedures, the Audit Office recommends:
steps be taken to ensure the returned review forms be actioned promptly; that continuing entitlement be confirmed; and that all factors affecting the amount paid be considered more closely

In its assessment of the Fightback document, the Department of Finance claimed that, while it accepted that $14m would be saved from tightened administration of sickness allowance, there would be additional administrative costs of about $7.5m entailed in these initiatives. The coalition does not agree that such large administration costs will be entailed in these initiatives, as the benefit recipient will be required to provide the second medical certificate. The coalition has not provided details in Fightback! as to the percentage of the total net savings of $52.7m which will be derived from tightening administration rather than increasing the waiting period. However, given the Auditor-General's findings, it is reasonable to believe that the net savings which are contained in Fightback! may be very conservative figures indeed.

PARA.TAB: This Auditor-General's report—thank heavens there is still somebody in this place who can be independent, not sullied by party politics—has shown that there are still some savings to be made and targeted to the population to which the benefits are directed and that the furphies and the claims made by the former Minister for Social Security that we are out to rip money from the poor and sick are nonsense. He and his Party do not have the monopoly on compassion.

If we had a system in place where people did not think that computers were gods, where they actually attended to the detail and where they did not use computer errors as excuses, we might find that people's privacy was protected. If the Department took more care to implement the legislation and to ensure that the benefits were targeted to those who were entitled to them, then, as I said, there would be more for those who genuinely needed it and maybe less of a burden for the taxpayer to have to bear, given the current economic climate.

The Auditor-General's report is very worthwhile reading. I commend the office for the work it has done. I ask the Department to address the issues and not just to say that the changes that were brought in in November 1991, with the sickness benefit being replaced by sickness allowance, deal with some of these issues. I do not think that is the case. The Department should pay very close attention to the report and look to the savings that can be made.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 20 of 1991-92, Project Audits—Department of Defence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This report is the third by the Auditor-General on Defence Department activities for the current financial year. It examines eight areas, including personnel and pay systems, an armament stores supply system, Navy victualling, trade repairs by civilian contractors and protective security. Before dealing with this report, I want to register my support for the continuing scrutiny of Defence expenditure by the Australian National Audit Office. There is far too little independent scrutiny of Defence expenditure for the simple reason that it is the one area of public spending which has been regarded as sacrosanct and exempt from the usual questioning to which government programs are normally subjected.

PARA.TAB: Of the eight areas examined in this report, only two were found to be satisfactory. Significant problems were identified in the remaining six. I shall refer to only four of them by way of example. In examining the Army personnel and pay system, the Auditor found a general lack of satisfactory independent checks of input data relating to pay variations of military personnel. In examining the civilian pay system, the Auditor-General suggested that improvements were necessary to internal controls, including more effective division of duties and control over password security.

In the armament stores and the computerised supply system for these stores the Auditor-General identified a general need for operational instructions and guidelines and an improvement in system management. In dealing with protective security, the Auditor-General recommended that a number of weaknesses should be referred to the Department for attention.

I acknowledge that the Defence Department has given commitments to address and correct these problems. However, it gives little cause for comfort that a lack of adequate financial control has been identified in so many areas by the Audit Office. As the Auditor-General states in the report, the situation could by no means be regarded as satisfactory. I am convinced that the Defence Department has been shielded from adequate scrutiny for so long that many more such problems have yet to be brought to light.
I commend the Audit Office and look forward to further reports on Defence Department programs, in particular the larger spending items such as the frigate and submarine programs.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: ARTS, SPORT, ENVIRONMENT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992
The Arts, Sport, Environment and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 amends 7 Acts administered in the ASET Portfolio.
The amendments are mainly to make the administration of various Government programs more efficient and cost effective.

The addition of new section 20A to the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988 will introduce a Ministerial power of direction in relation to the draft Territory Plan where the Territory planning authority continues to object to any aspect of the draft Plan prepared by the National Capital Planning Authority.
