This power will be limited to the recovery of costs reasonably associated with the application and they must not be set at such levels that they would amount to taxation.
The following amendments are made to the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990:
international anti-doping agreements will be recognised in the Act, allowing greater cooperation between the Commonwealth and other countries regarding the listing of defaulting competitors;

the reporting requirements as regards negative test results are widened so as to accommodate sports organisations that have contracted with the Agency that require confirmation of a negative test result prior to recognising records and awarding medals. Competitors will also be advised of who will be notified if they return a negative test result or if they refuse to provide a sample;
the Agency will be provided with the standard tax exemptions granted to Commonwealth statutory authorities;

the Agency will be given the power to delegate a number of its powers under the Act to any of its employees. The Agency comprises a relatively small number of specialist staff, and such a power of delegation is considered appropriate to ensure the efficiency of the Agency's functions.

The amendments to the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 and the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 will facilitate the giving of evidence by expert analysts and overcome any gaps in evidence in judicial proceedings.

Addition of botanic gardens under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 will enable the Norfolk Island Botanical Garden and the Australian National Botanical Garden, as well as any other park or reserve created in the future, to be managed as a botanic garden through a plan of management under the Act. Three international agreements are also added to the Schedule in respect of which the Governor-General will be empowered to make regulations.

The amendment to the Norfolk Island Act 1979 will permit the Acting Administrator and Deputy Administrator to exercise the powers of the Administrator when the Administrator is absent from duty, for example, on recreation leave, without actually being physically absent from the Territory.

Under the amendment to the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act 1986, the National Cultural Heritage Committee will be given the power to approve a recommendation or report under section 10 or 10A without the need to convene a meeting. This will enable those members of the Committee who are eligible to consider the issue to accept a recommendation or report by signing a document detailing the terms of their acceptance.

This will remove any question concerning the legality of a procedure that has already on several occasions been successfully adopted by the Committee, while at the same time ensuring that it can only be adopted if all members agree to the sign the relevant document.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
FOREST CONSERVATION AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1991

This legislation fulfils an undertaking made by the Prime Minister in the March statement to introduce Forest Conservation and Development Legislation to better protect Australia's native forests and concurrently facilitate much needed value adding investment and jobs in Australia's forest industries. The legislation will do so in a transparent and predictable way.
In short, this policy initiative is a major reform. This Government is deeply committed to reforms that will produce secure, long term jobs for the people of Australia.

It is always possible for Governments to grasp short term expedients in the quest for creating jobs. But these almost always mean the jettisoning of longer term, and often critical objectives, such as protecting Australia's environmental and cultural heritage.
This is not the way for this Government—it never has been and never will be.

This legislation is the result of long, careful and hard analysis; of careful consideration of the views of the ACTU and timber unions, environmental and industry groups; and of much consultation with the States and Territories including at the Special Premiers' Conference in July 1991. It has been constructed with our sights firmly set on the imperative of ecologically sustainable development—the proposition that we can and must reconcile legitimate concerns to preserve the values of our forests for current and future generations of Australians, and the equally legitimate concerns to use those same resources to advance other community objectives, through the development of value adding forest industries.

Industry must have—and I believe to a large degree does have—the same objective of conserving the value of our forests for future uses—for without such an active commitment there can be no long term future for the industry itself.

PARA.TAB: This constructive balance of what are always competing, if not conflicting, resource usages, is embodied in the legislation being introduced into the Parliament today.
I will now outline the features of the legislation for honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: Objectives of the Bill

PARA.TAB: The principal concurrent objectives of this Bill are to provide security and certainty to both the forestry industry, and to the Australian community

SPEECH.PARA: to provide security and certainty to industry so it can make significant long term investments with confidence that Governments of the future will not prevent or obstruct that investment's productive outcome

to provide security and certainty to the Australian community that all of its interests, whether they be for values that are environmental, cultural, heritage, social or economic—both for the current and future generations—are adequately and comprehensively safeguarded.

PARA.TAB: This Bill does not attempt to confer any new powers on the Commonwealth or on any minister; rather it establishes a method of integrating a broad range of processes under existing Commonwealth laws and regulations. At the same time it also provides a mechanism to integrate similar State and Territory Government processes with the Commonwealth's, in a constructive, time-saving and co-operative manner.
I will now outline the conditions relating to the granting of resource security.

SPEECH.PARA: Enterprise

PARA.TAB: First of all, the proponent must satisfy the Commonwealth that it has a legal standing as an enterprise in the meaning of the terms of this Bill. That is, the enterprise is a duly constituted company, partnership or a joint venture.

We have recognised in the legislation that, in particular with large scale investments of the kind envisaged here, it often may not be possible or practicable for a single company to undertake a project. But this should not be interpreted to mean a mere collection of sawmills could club together for the purposes of qualifying for resource security. Because the Government desires to promote value-adding industries, its approach to legislative resource security is based on a project rather than a region.

SPEECH.PARA: Dominant Purpose

PARA.TAB: The Wood Processing Project's dominant purpose must be to make a new investment of at least $100 million to produce goods for export and/or for import replacement. This legislation is not designed to protect the industrial status quo by providing security to any use of wood for any purpose from any region. It is designed to shift the industry towards export oriented, value adding activities and to facilitate large projects of that kind.

World scale pulp mills are, of course, the paradigm case and we want to see such developments at the earliest opportunity. But, again the Government has recognised, and acknowledged in this legislation, the commercial reality that investments of this size may also be made up of a set of integrated activities. This does not mean we would countenance a mere collection of sawmills as being eligible for resource security; we will only consider a proposal if it emanates from a company or group of companies whose activities are genuinely integrated. For example, such a proposal might involve, but not be limited to, a large scale sawmill, a veneer plant, a flitch mill, a woodchip plant to process the residues, and the establishment of plantations as a further resource base.

We have also recognised that significant large scale investments of the type we are endeavouring to encourage, can and do arise when companies expand or extend their existing facilities, perhaps through modernising or upgrading. The legislation enables this type of expansion to be eligible for resource security, provided it involves a substantial increase in the amount or the value of goods produced.

SPEECH.PARA: $100 Million Threshold

PARA.TAB: Many detractors of the Bill criticise it for the requirement that a project must cross the $100 million threshold before we will consider its eligibility. Let me remind honourable senators that it was industry that initially sought resource security for major investments—and investments which at the time were referred to as being in the hundreds of millions, and even billions of dollars.

We are determined to focus on investments of this size in the context of this legislation, because what the Government is offering to industry is not being done lightly. We are saying to industry, we the Government of Australia, after conducting a comprehensive integrated assessment, and satisfying ourselves that certain obligations have been entered into by the enterprise and the State Government, that we tie ourselves by legislation not to use our statutory powers, except in exceptional circumstances. This, for any government, is an enormously important decision. We are willing to take it to facilitate investments of high value in the national interest.
We have not, in producing this legislation, ignored the bulk of the forest products industry. I will return to this theme a little later, however, after I have completed the description of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Commercial Plantations

PARA.TAB: This Bill gives force to the Government's clear and unambiguous policy of excluding from eligibility for resource security any project whose dominant purpose is the export of logs or woodchips from native forests. As a further concrete way of underpinning this objective, the Commonwealth considers it necessary for industry proponents seeking resource security, as well as the Governments involved, to give appropriate consideration to the establishment, maintenance and use of forestry plantations.

As a further boost to this policy, we have recognised the need to encourage investment in commercial plantations. Such investment—for export of woodchips, or to provide resource for downstream processing, or both—will be eligible for consideration for resource security under this legislation. Where the proposal is to export woodchips we would need to be satisfied they would be surplus to domestic requirements—that is, surplus to the needs of downstream processing operations.
Consideration of resource security for this proposal would not include any woodchip from native hardwood forests. And, of course, the other criteria—including the $100 million threshold—must be met.
It is expected that together with the Government's other policy initiatives on plantations, this legislation will encourage a significant increase in the area of commercial plantations in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Up-Front Assessment

PARA.TAB: The real antecedents of this legislation can be found in industry's feelings of uncertainty, engendered by fear of the Commonwealth using its powers to remove significant tracts of forest from productive investments. We do not accept the validity of that perception, but we do accept that it exists and influences investment decisions.

The hugely important point for industry that the Government acknowledges in this legislation, is that once a company has taken a major investment decision, following government giving the green light, it should not be for the Government to intervene later to thwart the product of that investment in anything other than the most exceptional circumstances.

The only way any government can have the confidence to renounce using its undoubted and legitimate powers, is if it has first conducted a thorough and comprehensive integrated assessment of the project; and in conducting such an assessment, to have assured itself that all matters that fall within its responsibility have been addressed and, where appropriate and necessary, decisions considered and responsibly made.
This legislation carefully spells out the nature of that assessment. It after all is the basis on which the Government's guarantee not to use its powers, stands or falls. In this regard the Bill

SPEECH.PARA: says the assessment will cover all of the values likely to be affected: environmental, cultural, heritage, social and economic
says that the Australian Heritage Commission must have a reasonable opportunity to consider and comment on matters that are within its ambit
says that all the processes under the Commonwealth's Environment Protection (impact of proposals) Act have to be complied with.

PARA.TAB: The integrated assessment process will also include the application of the World Heritage Convention and the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, together with provisions under the Aboriginal heritage legislation.

This legislation does not water down the Government's environmental policies or its legislation. To the contrary; what it does do is ensure that environmental issues are taken into account when and as they should be: up-front, comprehensively, decisively, once and for all for the life of the project.

It is wrong to suggest as some critics have, that applying the assessment provisions of the resource security legislation up-front, is tantamount to the Government abrogating its responsibility to protect the environment.
On the other side, many industry and some State critics have suggested that such a thorough and comprehensive assessment will be too time consuming and will duplicate State activities.

Let me make this very clear—we will conduct assessments as fast as possible consistent with the thoroughness needed to provide the very certainty industry and unions want. There will be no undue duplication either of efforts or assessments between the Commonwealth and the States. It is the Government's intention—indeed it will be the legal requirement under section 12(4) of the Bill—that the Commonwealth assessment process must as far as practicable be integrated and co-ordinated with that of the State.
As an example of co-operative federalism I am sure this legislation will be outstanding.

The Commonwealth accepts that, provided all its assessment requirements are met before final approval is given and legislative resource security is provided, the assessment process can take place in two steps if a State wishes.

A State may wish to propose that a quantity of resource is required from a particular area of forest for a particular purpose. In the first step the Commonwealth and the State would develop and apply an integrated process to ensure all their relevant respective requirements were met. If, as a result, such a use of the resource were judged by each to be acceptable the Commonwealth would indicate that this is its view.

The second step would then comprise Commonwealth and State assessment of a specific project proposal. Again in this second step the Commonwealth and the State would develop and apply an integrated process to ensure all their relevant respective requirements were met. Requirements would not be reapplied except to the extent that knowledge of the specific plant and resource proposal, including the linkage between plant and resource, raised issues not covered in the first step consideration.
Legislative resource security would follow the final approval of the project upon completion of the second step.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreements Between the Commonwealth, State and Enterprise

PARA.TAB: When the Commonwealth issues a declaration that a project has resource security it will do so on the basis of formal written agreements between it and the State in which the project is to be conducted, and between the State and the enterprise. These agreements will be public and they will be legally binding—with the sanction against a serious breach being the potential withdrawal of resource security and a return to the existing situation of perceived comparative uncertainty. These agreements, together with the integrated up-front assessment, are the foundation of resource security. They will contain the undertakings of the three parties that will be essential to a successful and ongoing project. These are, in essence

SPEECH.PARA: an undertaking by a State to provide the necessary volume of resources for the project
an undertaking by the Commonwealth not to exercise its powers to prevent or obstruct the project
an undertaking by the enterprise in relation to its conduct of the project.

PARA.TAB: As well as such undertakings, the agreements will be required to incorporate other provisions or procedures that are critical to all parties having confidence that resource security will work in practice. These include

SPEECH.PARA: provisions requiring the State to monitor and enforce compliance with environmental management practices that the enterprise will be obliged to undertake;
a provision allowing the Commonwealth to monitor the State's compliance with its obligation to enforce any obligations imposed on the enterprise;
provisions requiring consultation on the agreement at any of the signatories' request;
provisions requiring specific cooperation and consultation when the Commonwealth may contemplate using the exceptions provisions; and
provisions covering procedures for renegotiation and termination of the agreement.
How Secure is Resource Security?

PARA.TAB: The project having been judged eligible, the up-front assessment having been done, and the agreements concluded; just how secure is a project's access to its necessary volume of resources? Will the Commonwealth really stand back and let the enterprise get on with it? Won't the Commonwealth dream up new (or revisit old) ways to negate an enterprise's investment decision? Just how "secure" is resource security?

As has been repeatedly stated, this government is not in the business of abrogating its environmental (or any other) responsibilities. Of course we recognise—as do the States with whom we have discussed this issue at length, and as do industry and unions—that things can change, that events can occur that are totally unforeseen, that exceptional situations can arise.

Recognising these realities of life, we have stated unequivocally and clearly in the Bill what those circumstances have to be, before the Commonwealth will wish to take a second look at the way a project with legislated resource security is being conducted.

Honourable senators should be aware that this Bill does not make it easy either for the Commonwealth to remove resource security, or for a minister to exercise a power that has been made dormant by the granting of resource security. The circumstances involved are remote and they are unexpected. And there is nothing automatic about these processes.

It is the Government's intention that before any minister can consider whether or not to take any action, consultation will take place not only between government ministers, but also with the parties to the agreements in accordance with procedures laid down in those agreements.

There are five potential circumstances set out in the Bill under which ministers might need to reactivate their dormant powers. These are all exceptional circumstances and the Government would not contemplate invoking dormant powers other than for those exceptional circumstances. The five exceptions are:
First, in order

SPEECH.PARA: to prevent a "major physical impact" on the natural environment or Australia's cultural heritage, or
to prevent a species of flora or fauna becoming threatened, or more threatened, or
to prevent a substantial adverse effect on a "physical feature or thing" that is part of the cultural or natural heritage or national estate, or on a significant Aboriginal area or object
but only where these circumstances were not foreseen and had not been assessed up-front.

PARA.TAB: A species will be declared as threatened only after ministers are satisfied that an adequate scientific basis exists and only after there has been appropriate consultation with the States and their views taken into account.

The second exception concerns the use of Commonwealth powers during the construction or commissioning stages, simply where it was not practicable to do so during the assessment stage (for example to test some part of the plant that by definition cannot be done earlier); this section only relates to powers relevant to the construction or operation of the project.

The third exception relates to matters quite extraneous to the up-front environmental, cultural, heritage, social and economic issues assessment, simply to cover such matters as acquiring land for defence purposes, or blocking exports under United Nations' sanctions.
The fourth matter which obviously must be covered is a material breach of an agreement.
The fifth matter covers failure to comply with conditions or requirements imposed as a result of, during or after, the assessment process.
The Government believes that it is better to spell out with precision what these highly restricted circumstances will be, rather than to leave industry in the dark by the use of a general statement.
Two final matters to bring to honourable senators' attention are;

SPEECH.PARA: this Bill will not affect taxation or foreign investment review powers, and

this Bill will involve the exercise of responsibilities of several portfolios. Overall responsibility for the legislation will be with the Prime Minister and responsibility for particular sections will be designated to other relevant ministers as appropriate. The division of portfolio responsibilities is set out in the explanatory memorandum.
Non-Legislated Resource Security

PARA.TAB: I mentioned before that this Government did not intend to ignore the position of the bulk of the industry's hardwood sawmilling sector. Because of the enormous significance of the Government tying its hands in legislation not to use its powers, Government will only apply the Bill to very large investments of amounts exceeding $100m. Of course the bulk of forest industry cannot be comprehended by the legislation.

The Government has approved a non-legislative form of resource security that will go a long way to providing the type of security this part of the industry is seeking—and at the same time encourage restructuring towards a more competitive industry for the future providing more and better jobs for Australians.

The arrangements to be offered by the Commonwealth—through formal Commonwealth-State agreements—are similar to the provisions in the Bill, in that they include a comprehensive up-front assessment covering all Commonwealth responsibilities for environmental, cultural, heritage, social and economic matters; intergovernmental agreements between the Commonwealth and State; State-enterprise contracts; as well as provisions to accommodate changing circumstances of an exceptional nature.

The type of project we envisage could well use these arrangements, is for example a sawmilling enterprise within a prescribed area, such as the New South Wales south east forests. The Commonwealth would require a number of provisions:

SPEECH.PARA: that the enterprise must be willing to commit either to the value adding investment or to industry restructuring

the relevant State Government must be prepared to offer a longer term, contractually based supply licence for sawlogs to enable the investment to proceed, such as has been the case in Victoria and Western Australia

the woodchip export company must have invested, or be prepared to invest, in other value adding activities in Australia, either in sawmilling enterprises or commercial plantations and agree that domestic value adding of the woodchips has priority over their use for export.

PARA.TAB: To the extent that the Commonwealth is involved in export licensing in the region concerned, it will offer a longer term export licence up to the year 2000 and thereafter on a case by case basis, on the understanding that if the woodchips are required for domestic use then, subject to market consideration, they should be directed to that end. This should not detract from the Commonwealth's firm desire to achieve maximum domestic processing of woodchips by the year 2000 or soon thereafter.
The Government intends to discuss this proposal now with both the States and industry. We are confident, as I said before, that it will meet many if not all of this sector of the industry's concerns.

With the combination of the legislated resource security for large projects and the framework of enhanced intergovernmental agreements for others in the industry, the Government is offering a powerful and unprecedented package which delivers security, and an incentive for restructuring in an environmentally responsible framework. I believe industry will accept the offer.

SPEECH.PARA: Concluding Remarks

PARA.TAB: Before commending this Bill to the consideration of honourable senators, might I remind the House that the Bill and the non-legislated policy initiative for the hardwood sawmilling sector are concerned with achieving the following key objectives

SPEECH.PARA: ensuring the forest environment and heritage, cultural values are adequately considered in a transparent and predictable framework prior to development proceeding;
facilitating much needed value adding investments in the forests sector, including commercial plantations;
creating more and better jobs for Australians who earn an honest living from this industry.

PARA.TAB: Provided the forest industries hold to their commitment to invest—as the public is entitled to expect—Australia will benefit from worldscale value adding investments before the year 2000.
This legislation has the capacity to pave the way for a pulpmill proposal in northern Tasmania and an expansion of the existing mill at Maryvale in Victoria.

Other major investments are envisaged for later in the decade in Western Australia and East Gippsland in Victoria. Of particular importance is the role of commercial plantations in providing the necessary feedstock to sustain these developments.

The Government believes it is steering a path, consistent with its environmental objectives, to create a better and more productive industry; an industry which can become the base for a sophisticated papermaking industry in the future, providing more jobs for Australians and more prosperity for our nation.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT)ADMINISTRATIVE APPEALS TRIBUNAL REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Family Law Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 447 and made under the Family Law Act 1975, be disallowed.
That the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 450 and made under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: This disallowance motion of the Australian Democrats has been made necessary by the Government's extraordinary attempt to impose yet another cost on people involved in Family Court litigation. The crux of the new regulations is regulation 16A, which provides for the introduction of a $500 hearing fee. This hearing fee has been popularly termed a setting down fee, and I shall use that term. The fee is payable when a court, a judge or a registrar fixes a date for the hearing in the Family Court of an application or an issue or question in an application or an appeal to the Full Court, whether from a decision of the Family Court or from a decision in another court.

PARA.TAB: People do not choose to go to the Family Court; they are compelled to seek a legal resolution of conflicts arising out of a marriage breakdown, which often involves access and custody of children. The Government proposes to burden these people at this most traumatic time of their lives with an extra $500 fee that they cannot avoid and, in most cases, simply cannot afford.

In a typical Family Court case, there would be an application for dissolution of marriage which would necessitate at that point an initial $300 filing fee plus, of course, the parties' own legal costs. It has been estimated that the cost of a typical all-inclusive custody hearing comprising only one or two days in court with no complications ranges from $5,000 to $8,000. Hard fought custody cases, involving complicated issues such as allegations of child sexual abuse, might require 20 court days and hearing costs of $2,000 to $3,000 a day.

In relation to disputes over matrimonial property, it has been estimated that matters proceeding to trial would have costs ranging between $3,000 to $10,000. Here I am talking of the average, everyday cases handled by the Family Court. We know that of all the divorces in Australia, only about 5 per cent finish up in court. Some States are fortunate to have a much lower percentage. In Tasmania, the figure is only 1 1/2 per cent, due to intensive counselling.

I am not talking here of those extreme cases which have been reported to a number of government and Senate inquiries currently in progress—the cost of justice inquiry and the Family Court inquiry. Cases have been noted which finish up costing $100,000 or $150,000 and, in one memorable instance, $250,000. I am referring to those cases which involve ordinary people who are forced to litigate their differences because they are not part of that fortunate 95 per cent. They are forced to go to a court to resolve their differences. We find that, in addition to those average costs, which are already an extremely difficult load for them, they are now going to be faced with an extra $500 imposed by the Australian Government. We should note that the Government is surely aware that the legal system in Australia is, at present, undergoing some very detailed scrutiny by those inquiries that I have mentioned. Knowing that, one can only conclude that the introduction of a $500 setting down fee is clearly an intentional abdication by the Federal Government of its responsibility to improve access to justice.

The Government will, no doubt, say that the exemptions contained in regulation 16(2) adequately cover people who cannot afford the $500 fee. The exemptions do include people receiving legal aid and others at the lower end of the income scale. However, it is important to note that there is a large number of Australians who are unable to meet the stringent legal aid criteria but who still cannot afford the steeply rising costs of our legal system. For example, in the ACT a person with two dependants will no longer be entitled to legal aid if he or she has a gross income of over $283 per week. How can someone on that low income afford an extra $500?

In addition, figures indicate that not only in the ACT, but all over Australia, the number of rejected legal aid applicants has sharply increased. Victoria is one of the hardest hit States, with a rejection rate of over 40 per cent of legal aid applicants. Clearly, this squeeze, due to the rising demand for legal aid services and a reduction in funds available, is reducing the number of people who are able to avail themselves of legal aid and who therefore would fall under this exemption.

There is another provision which the Government will point to. The proposed regulations do permit the courts' registrar to waive the $500 fee `on the ground that payment of the fee would impose financial hardship on the person'. But why should people be subjected to the additional process by having to apply for an exemption to that fee? The individual concerned would face the stigma of pleading financial hardship to obtain what is every citizen's right—access to the legal system. The registrar is to have regard to the `income, assets and liabilities of the person liable to pay the fee', but there are no other criteria and the discretion is therefore entirely in the registrar's hands, making the litigant very much a supplicant. This is clearly an untenable situation.

If the Government wants to recover a proportion of court costs I would suggest that it should instead establish a user-pays court for corporations and tax disputes above $5m. This method would be seen as a much more efficient way of recouping some of the expenditure that the Government now has in the court system. I welcome the support of the coalition parties for my disallowance motion, no doubt influenced by the evidence some of its members have received, as I have, in the Family Court inquiry and the cost of justice inquiry.

I also welcome the coalition parties' support for my motion of disallowance No.4 of the $200 setting down fee in the AAT. Clearly this setting down fee should not apply to a tribunal where approximately 70 per cent of the applications lodged in the 1989-90 were concerned with workers' compensation, social security and veterans' entitlements legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, of course, wishes to resist the motion from Senator Spindler to disallow regulations which impose certain fees in the family law jurisdiction and in the jurisdiction of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. We do so because we believe it is proper that those who approach those jurisdictions make some contribution to the cost of the provision of a way of resolving a matter which has all the sanction, authority and status of a court or a tribunal of such significance as the AAT.

PARA.TAB: The fee is not designed to reduce access to the courts or to tribunals for the resolution of disputes in our society to the status of just another commodity or asset to be bought in

SPEECH.PARA: the marketplace. It does not mean that only those who are wealthy enough can utilise this very important function or power in our society which is exercised by judges or those who sit on various benches and tribunals. That would be totally unacceptable.

PARA.TAB: If the motivation for Senator Spindler moving this motion and the Opposition supporting it is that they are of a view that access to justice is too important a matter in our society—which is governed by the rule of law—to be left simply to the marketplace to determine who can afford it, I would be in agreement with them. But when we look at the way in which the regulations are structured, one finds that there is indeed no intention on the part of the Federal Government to deny to those who cannot afford to pay the fees which are set down in these regulations access to the Family Court or to the AAT. For example, a person liable, or who might otherwise be liable, to pay the fee but who is a recipient of legal aid is not required to pay the fee. Of course, that is only sensible.

Nor should a person pay the fee who is the holder of a pensioner health benefit card, a health benefit card, a pharmaceutical benefits concession card, or a health care card; nor should an inmate of a prison, somebody lawfully detained in a public institution, a child under the age of 18 years, or a person in receipt of Austudy. Not only are those specific grounds set out, but also, if a registrar, having regard to the income, assets and liabilities of the person liable to pay the fee, is of the view that the payment of the fee would impose financial hardship on the person, once again the fee can be waived.

So I believe it is important just to point out that we are not trying to create a situation, which would be intolerable in our sort of society, whereby the imposition of a series of fees made it impossible for people to seek the assistance of the courts to resolve a dispute, in the case of the two matters we are concerned with, before the Family Court or the AAT.

In addition, without bending the knee or bowing the head to the ideology of user pays unnecessarily, I believe that there is also an argument that it is not unreasonable for those who use these very expensive services provided by society to resolve a dispute by invoking the assistance of this particular part of our social structure—certainly in the case of the Family Court which has proved perhaps not amenable to counselling, mediation or any of the other means which would allow settlement to be reached before one needs to approach a judge to determine and rule on the disputed matter, whether it be custody, property or whatever—for the sake of the great majority of other persons in our society who have to pay taxes to uphold these institutions to ask the person approaching the court to make not full payment but a contribution. That is what we have in mind in setting down the list of fees for the Family Court.

Indeed, although this is not the primary motive, if the imposition of these fees leads to some incentive for parties to perhaps think twice about whether they might not be able to resolve the matter before requiring the judgment of the court, that would be a good side effect. But, basically, the fees are being levied in order to assist the Federal Government to discharge its obligation to fund the system of justice, which we are obliged to do if our society is to remain one governed by the rule of law, and the contribution, running into some millions of dollars, certainly would be very helpful in that regard.

As to the question of the amount that people might be required to pay, I think it is worth dispelling some of the more outrageous estimates that have been bandied around in certain letters that have been received by honourable senators. There is no doubt, of course, that the fees will add at least $100 to all applications made to the Family Court, unless of course the parties seek consent orders, in which case no fee is payable. In most cases, it is estimated that the additional cost will be about $200, that being an application fee plus one or two interim or interlocutory applications. In that situation, when one looks at the fees that are paid to the lawyers—without taking into account GST on the legal fees of course; I am speaking about the present, not some perilous future in regard to the question of lawyers' fees—the $200 or so is not an extravagant amount to ask people to pay. It is not extravagant when one looks at the total cost that they will be asked to bear in relation to the legal advice and representation they receive.

As to the AAT—and I think Senator Spindler spoke to this in the course of his remarks—a hearing fee of $200 is to be payable on the setting down for hearing of an application for a review of an administrative decision. I think it is very important to note—and I know that Senator Macdonald will have noted this, but I do not know how much weight he has given to it—that the $200 hearing fee is not payable in those income maintenance matters such as social security matters and veterans' affairs matters. That is a very important and very proper concession. Of course, in such cases we are not talking about two persons in society who are in dispute and seeking the court's resolution of the matter, as is the case in the Family Court; we are talking about a person in society who believes he or she has an entitlement under the laws passed by this Parliament which has been denied by some bureaucratic decision and the person seeks to advance reasons why that denial should be reversed and the entitlement given. In that situation I think it is quite right and proper that the hearing fee of $200 should not be applied, and that is the case.

In so far as I have been able to discern any pattern in the correspondence which I have received, it is about the impact of the fees in the tax jurisdiction. It is the case that since 1987 when the AAT acquired its tax jurisdiction from the taxation boards of review the number of applications for review has dropped substantially. This may in part be attributed to the cost of making an application, which has increased—I think it was about $2 back in 1987—but I do not believe that that is by any means the total story. Self-assessment has also led to a reduction in the number of applications for review of assessments so that now the typical taxation matter involves substantial amounts of money. In that situation we also ought to note that the taxation system is currently being altered to provide for objections to be lodged directly with the AAT rather than by the Commissioner of Taxation. Taxpayers who object to a decision are given a free internal review of the assessment and should proceed to the AAT or the Federal Court only after having had the opportunity to properly assess the merits of their application.

So I believe that when one puts aside the income maintenance matter—social security and veterans' affairs—and simply looks, say, at the taxation matters the problem is not so large that it should lead the Senate to disallow these particular regulations. So the Government, of course, supports those regulations referred to in notices of motion Nos 1 and 4 dealing with the Family Court and the AAT fee structure which are before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I think Senator Spindler has moved his notice of motion No. 1.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—And No. 4.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to speak on all four. They all relate to the same sort of matter and it may save some time later if I indicate on behalf of the Liberal and National parties the attitude that we intend to take. We intend to support the disallowance motions foreshadowed in notices of motion Nos 1 and 4, but we will not support any disallowance motions in relation to the other two.

PARA.TAB: The coalition has given very serious consideration to the proposals that the Government announced in the Budget last year to charge a setting-down fee for the Federal Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. When I took the opportunity during the Senate Estimates process of pursuing the matter with the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) and officials of the Attorney-General's Department, I was advised that the proposal to introduce setting-down fees arose from a review of fees in Commonwealth courts and tribunals which involved a number of Commonwealth departments and agencies.

In order to gain some understanding of the reasons behind the decisions to implement these fees, the shadow Attorney-General, the Hon. Andrew Peacock, has asked the Department on a number of occasions since 13 February for a copy of this report, which apparently has the status of an intradepartmental working document. The copy, unfortunately, was eventually provided only late yesterday, and this was some hours after the shadow Ministry had completed its considerations on the matter, and the information contained in the report—some 38 pages plus lengthy schedules—was not able to be taken into consideration. Up until that time, the only documentation on the reasons for the decision to introduce setting-down fees has been a press release of the Attorney-General dated 18 December 1991 and the answers to some questions which were raised in the Estimates Committee on 5 September 1991 by me and, Madam Acting Deputy President, by you as well, and you will well recall that.
According to the press release issued by the Attorney-General, the justification for the imposition of these fees is that:

SPEECH.PARA: They will raise revenue which will return significant net benefit to the justice system.
In the Estimates Committee we asked the Minister whether these fees were simply a fundraising issue. I understood the Minister or his officials to agree that that was the case.

PARA.TAB: Mr Duffy noted in his press release that the total fee revenue covered only a very small portion of the total costs of running the courts and tribunals system. It has not been an easy matter to determine the forums in which the new fees would apply or the amount of the fees. In the Budget Speech, it was simply announced that there was to be a setting down fee in the Federal courts and the AAT of $500. I quote from the Budget Papers, which say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will introduce a new fee structure in federal courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, from September 1991—
that is pretty typical of government legislation; it proposes things for September and here we are some six months later still dealing with it—

with the aim of achieving a more equitable fee structure. The major change will be the introduction of a setting down fee of $500 in all jurisdictions—that is, a fee payable when a matter is ready to be listed for hearing.

Again, typical of this Government, it could not even get its Budget Papers right. It was telling us in these documents that it was $500 for all Federal courts plus the AAT. It only transpired from questioning in an Estimates committee some 10 days or so later, on 5 September, that the departmental officials then said for the first time that the AAT fee was to be only $200.

PARA.TAB: As I say, that is typical of this Government. It really does not know what it is doing. It has little idea of how to manage things and how to administer its departments. As I mentioned, it now transpires that it is the Government's intention to have that setting down fee of $500 in the Federal, Family and High courts and a fee of $200 in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

In respect of the Family Court—and this comes under notice of motion No. 1—a variety of fees covering other court services are also introduced in these regulations. The court will be required to impose fees of $100 covering originating applications; interlocutory applications of $50; a full court appeal in child support matters of $500; and appeals from magistrates, registrars and judicial registrars of $100. Similar charges are also made in relation to the Federal Court.

In terms of policy, the Liberal and National parties are of the view that it is of paramount importance to the swift, cost effective administration of justice that the whole Federal system of justice, including the High Court, be managed on sound, cost-disciplined administrative principles. The recent proposed cutbacks outlined in the Fightback package emphasise a streamlining of the administrative and bureaucratic arms of the justice system.

The coalition has been supportive of the current examination by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs into the costs of justice, legal services and litigation. The Committee's terms of reference require it to examine, amongst other things, the management of the courts and the level of government charges which are imposed upon litigants within the court system. The Committee, as you would well know, Madam Acting Deputy President, is yet to report on these topics.

Whilst it might be true to say that the coalition is not necessarily opposed to some measure of cost recovery where this will enhance sound management of the judicial system, we are concerned that the regulations currently on the table unnecessarily increase the cost of justice and cause significant hardship in some cases. The Law Council of Australia shares this concern and has indeed argued strongly that these regulations ought not be implemented.

Mr Duffy, again in typical fashion of this Government, dismissed the Law Society's criticisms in his press release of 18 September. In so doing, he had what I consider to be a fairly cheap shot at the profession. Mr Duffy said:

SPEECH.PARA: I find it particularly disappointing that a leader of the Australian legal profession consistently calls for more Government funding for the justice system, and yet complains when something constructive is done to providing additional money. The Australian public must be even more cynical about such criticisms when it is the restrictive trade practices and high fees of the legal profession which are the greatest single inhibitor to access to justice.

With respect, the coalition does not dismiss the Law Council's arguments so lightly. Again, the Minister takes the easy and popular way out by having a shot at the legal profession when he should be looking closer to home.

PARA.TAB: The Law Council's view is that it is the right of all citizens to have access on as equal a basis as possible to the court system provided by the Government. It is the responsibility of the Government to provide a justice system funded from the general revenue of all citizens who may need to use the system at some stage.

It is certainly the case that ordinary Australians may be inhibited by the introduction of the fees proposed in these regulations. For those who do not qualify for legal aid or fall within the list of exempted persons, access to the legal system would be more expensive. It is again the middle Australians who are being squeezed out.

I know that Senator Tate does not care too much about the people on lower incomes within Australia. Those receiving under $21,000 did not even feature in the `Dumb Nation' statement that was issued the other day by Mr Keating. The Government has no interest in those sort of people. That is also borne out in its attitude to these fees. It is more related in that instance to the middle income Australians—those who do not qualify for legal aid and yet are not in the wealthy bracket of the members of huge corporations and the big business people, the super rich people, who were so prominent in the Labor Party in the 1980s. It is that middle income group that miss out in this justice system. It is those sort of people who are hurt most by these fees being imposed.

Senator Tate mentioned in his speech that section 16 provided that certain people were excluded from the fees. I acknowledge that that is correct. But, again, those people on welfare benefits and in receipt of pensions and legal aid are affected. As Senator Spindler pointed out, one really has to be almost a pauper to receive legal aid these days. Since being in office, this Government has continuously forgotten about middle income people—the ordinary people of Australia; those people on $25,000 or $30,000; families with one person working and a couple of kids which are struggling to make their way. This has happened again with respect to these regulations.

The argument that some form of cost recovery is appropriate in the case of the High Court and the Federal Court can be more tenable than it is in relation to the Family Court and the AAT. This is due to the nature of the cases heard in these forums and the type of applications involved. We accept that in these cases it is appropriate that a small proportion of the total costs of running the justice system is recouped from the users of the system. The imposition of a setting down fee may also quite properly, as you would appreciate as a practitioner, Madam Acting Deputy President, act as a disincentive to the parties to signify readiness for hearing when in fact they are not prepared. If it does act as a disincentive, this will assist the courts in case flow management.

But the Liberal and National parties are concerned that significant hardship could result from the imposition of a setting down fee in the Family Court and in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This concern in relation to the Family Court is shared by the Law Council of Australia and by the Chief Justice of the Family Court.

A range of applications arise in actions in the Family Court which would be subject to the new fees. Examples of where such payments would be inappropriate include instances where a child is at risk of being snatched and taken interstate or overseas; action to gain proper access to a child where access is being refused by a vindictive custodial parent; action to vary an unreasonable assessment of child support under the Child Support Assessment Act; or action to remove a violent or abusive spouse from the matrimonial home. There are literally dozens of other examples in which the imposition of a setting down fee would be unfair.

I draw to the attention of the Senate the information given, I think by the Law Council of Australia, as to the typical case costs that could apply with the new fees in a typical Family Court case. My understanding is that these fees are quite relevant and not outrageously exaggerated. An initiating application would be $100; a subsequent application for property settlement would be $100; problems with child custody and access would be $100; an application for discovery would be $50; and a setting down fee would be $500—making a total of $850. If we then add to that the cost to which you, Madam Acting Deputy President, have drawn a lot of attention in the Estimates Committee of obtaining a transcript—taking three days as the length of an average trial, 120 pages per day at $6.50 to $8.50 per page, the cost being $780 to $1,020 per day for three days, making the cost of the transcript alone about $8,000—we are looking at about $8,850 just in court fees paid to the government before we start to look at the fees the lawyers will charge. This might even be amusing when we consider that the Family Court was first introduced as a court where no fees at all were payable; where justice could be obtained quickly, inexpensively and without all the rigmarole.

In conclusion, I refer again to the AAT. We agree that the regulations in relation to that tribunal should also be disallowed. That is on the basis that, with the nature of the tribunal and the often smaller claims involved, it would seem absurd to charge a setting down fee even at the reduced rate of $200 and even with a proviso that it would be refundable to successful applicants. The fact remains that if one is dealt with capriciously by a government department one would not be able to proceed with one's AAT hearing unless one comes up with the $200 fee to have one's case set down. Whilst Senator Tate says that there are not quite so many tax applications now, as I raised in the Estimates Committee, one does on occasions have the need to appeal tax decisions. They may not be for very large amounts, but if one is forking out $200 every time one wants to have an assessment looked at it certainly provides a huge disincentive to proceed to try to obtain justice in relation to one's taxation matters.

For these reasons, the coalition will be supporting the disallowance of regulations which impose a setting down fee on the Family Court and the AAT, but we will not be supporting the disallowance of those regulations which establish a setting down fee in relation to the High Court and the Federal Court of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Macdonald in his remarks and make a few brief remarks of my own. These regulations were gazetted on 19 December and are due to take effect on 1 April of this year. Perhaps that date is rather significant. This fee increase arose from a review of fees in the Commonwealth courts and tribunals by a number of departments and bodies, including the Attorney-General's Department and the various courts and tribunals. However, I will contain my remarks specifically to the Family Court of Australia.

PARA.TAB: As a member of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, I find the issue of increased fees quite inappropriate. Senator Spindler is on that Committee and I note that in his press release put out the other day he challenged the Opposition parties to support him. I do not quite know whether we are supporting Senator Spindler or he is actually supporting us in a couple of parts of the disallowance, but in his press release he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Exemptions in the regulations do cover people receiving legal aid and others at the lower end of the income scale. However, that does not cover the large number of people who do not meet the stringent legal aid criteria but still cannot afford the steeply rising costs of our legal system.

I think Senator Macdonald has also alluded to that. Although a Senate committee is investigating the cost of justice, quite large numbers of people have also seen fit to raise the issue of fees in relation to family law with the Committee looking into the interpretation of the Family Law Act. A very common story, which has been repeated everywhere we have convened in Australia, is that so often the value of the property of a marriage is totally or largely eroded by the paying out of quite extensive legal fees, let alone now putting fees into instruments in the Family Court.

PARA.TAB: For the Federal Labor Government at this time of severe recession to attack those who are least able to afford to pay the increased fees is totally inappropriate. The fees imposed in the Family Court include $100 for originating applications; $50 for interlocutory applications; $500 for full court appeals in child support matters; and $100 for appeals from magistrates, registrars and judicial registrars. These fees will all come on top of those charged by legal counsel engaged by the applicant for divorce. I know that Senator Macdonald gave a couple of examples where it would be clearly inappropriate for fees to be paid by a litigant in the Family Court. I mention several more examples: enforcing proper access orders being disobeyed by a custodial parent; determining what is in the genuine best interests of a child; stopping a child from being physically assaulted; preventing sexual interference with and abuse of a child; and obtaining urgent maintenance for a child or spouse. I believe it is totally inappropriate, particularly at this time of economic downturn with record numbers of unemployed and a rising divorce rate, to talk of increasing fees at this stage.

Opposition to the new fees does not just come from the politicians; the Law Council of Australia is also totally opposed to them. It is of the view that it is the right of all citizens to have access on as equal a basis as possible to the courts provided by the Government. The Law Council argues that it is the responsibility of the Government to provide a system of justice funded from general revenue for all citizens who may need to use that system. The family law section of the Law Council and the Chief Justice of the Family Court have been particularly concerned about the impact of these new regulations. Divorce is difficult enough without making it an option purely for the financially able, as Senator Macdonald alluded to a little while ago. Justice is supposed to be available equally to all, and clearly this is not the case with these regulations which make justice affordable only to the better off in society. That is not justice and that is not equitable. On those grounds, the regulations as enunciated by Senator Macdonald ought to be disallowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, with your indulgence I will be brief and general in my comments. I support the comments made by my colleagues on the disallowance regulations in respect of the AAT and the Family Court. I have long held the view that the general principle that courts of law ought to be available to all citizens is one that is frankly not true in Australia now and nor has it been for a very long time.

PARA.TAB: The capacity to get justice depends upon the capacity to pay. There are a number of reasons of course for that, but it is one of the great inequities of modern Australian society that if one finds oneself tempted to be involved in litigation one inevitably has to ask how much it will cost, what capacity one has to pay and what capacity the other person has to pay.

If one takes action against a very wealthy corporation or a very wealthy citizen, inevitably and invariably the advice one receives is to try to settle out of court. That is simply because one does not have equal access. In this day and age one does not have to go to the High Court; one could find oneself in either a district court or the Supreme Court. If a QC is involved the costs could be at least $25,000 a day. If one wants the best advocates, that is simply what one has to pay.

There are probably many reasons for that, but on the question of access to legal advice itself I think it was the Chief Justice of Western Australia who said that the price of justice is way beyond the scope of many Western Australian citizens and that lawyers' fees contributed significantly to that. Many of the larger law firms had geared themselves for business with large corporations. They structured themselves in such a way—offices and facilities—that their hourly costs were driven up and, therefore, an ordinary citizen had to share the burden of those costs if he or she wanted proper access to that firm's advice.

I thought that Senator Tate was a man of the people until he was elevated to his present position. I am surprised to find that he is not embarrassed by being involved in a circumstance which further puts access to the courts, justice and liberty beyond the reach of ordinary citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —He does look embarrassed.

—He is simply blushing for our benefit. Neither the Liberal Party nor the coalition would support a further onus on the cost of justice. Again, we find a government that purports to represent the poor, the underprivileged and the deprived casting upon them another cost in life which puts them further behind in their daily living. I support the position taken by my colleagues.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the motion to disallow certain fees to be paid in relation to matters in the High Court and the Federal Court, as already alluded to or indicated in Senator Spindler's speech, it is possible—and no doubt the Opposition is relying on this possibility—to distinguish between the general run of those who might come before the Family Court or the AAT and those who pursue a matter before the High Court or the Federal Court.

In that respect Senator Macdonald was right to indicate in his remarks that a small proportion of the costs—and it is a very small proportion of the costs—of providing for the operation of these courts ought to be recovered from those litigants before either of those courts.

I was also interested in some earlier remarks made by Senator Spindler to the effect that he could support the idea that in those cases where, for example, one has two major corporations seeking to carry a major battle over boardroom control into the courts, or a major taxation matter involving a huge corporation with plenty of resources, a case could be made out, as Senator Spindler was beginning to, that one could even have full cost recovery in those cases so that where the courts are utilised in that way by those major corporations to resolve disputes, which is another way of trying to resolve the dispute, they could make full payment.

One thinks of the new arbitration arrangements that are emerging, and I know Senator Durack has taken a keen interest in that. I think Sir Laurence Street, in relation to commercial arbitration matters both within Australia and internationally in our region, has been at the forefront of those who have sought to provide a system for resolving disputes that does not require an exercise of the judicial power but rather some sort of arbitration between the parties concerned. No doubt they pay very fully for the opportunity to use that particular way to resolve the dispute.

I think I might take Senator Spindler's hint. I might further build on the fact that Senator Macdonald has said that some small proportion of the total cost is properly recoverable. I do believe that these particular fees to be imposed in relation to those who can afford to pay in the Federal Court and High Court should be supported by the Senate. TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There are no plans to increase the number of migrants from the former Soviet Union simply because of the prospect of a terrible winter. However, to ensure the fairest access to Australia's migration programs for citizens of the former Soviet Union while also making provision for repressed minorities, who may need our assistance, the Government has undertaken two things this year. One is to provide a share of places among the 4,000 the Minister recently announced under the new Special Assistance category for people who are members of ethnic minorities in the former Soviet Union. The Special Assistance category was created in recognition of the continuing strong community support for the humanitarian component of our migration program and is designed to ensure that Australia can respond to special circumstances without being constrained by problems of definition. The disarray in government services delivery within the new republics makes Special Assistance numbers from the former Soviet Union this year uncertain. However, the selection of people under the new category will target those in greatest need of assistance. It will focus on the degree of distress an individual has suffered as a result of severe civil disorder or violence or because he or she is a member of a disadvantaged or repressed minority, and also on the extent of the person's links with Australia.

The second Government initiative this year has been to set up a travel loan fund to help up to 6,000 migrants come here from Eastern Europe (including the former USSR), who meet normal selection criteria for the Independent Category. The Minister announced last year that the travel loan fund scheme will operate for a three year period and that migrants will be expected to repay loans over a two year period starting six months after their arrival in Australia. The travel loan fund was set up in recognition of the serious practical barriers currency restrictions in the former USSR and other East European countries impose on skilled migration from these countries and to ensure that Australia is not denied access to a highly skilled group of people being actively sought by other countries.
(2) Between 1945 and 1955 approximately 457,000 European migrants (excluding those from the United Kingdom and Ireland) arrived for a permanent or long-term stay in Australia.

(3) Population census data provides an indication of the net population increase (overseas arrivals minus overseas departures minus deaths) of the European-born. Between the 1947 and 1954 censuses the European-born increased by 132,768 in Victoria; 121,404 in New South Wales; 46,377 in South Australia; 39,533 in Western Australia; 29,392 in Queensland; 9,088 in Tasmania; 3,058 in the Australian Capital Territory and 753 in the Northern Territory.

(4) No research has been done specifically on the long-term benefits to the Australian economy of the intake of European migrants following World War II. In general terms, however, the latest research indicates the following long-term benefits of migration to the Australian economy:
a contribution to the growth in size of the domestic market, resulting in economies of scale and expanded aggregate output, consumption and investment;
a lift in the average quality of the labour force through the provision of skilled and unskilled labour;
growth in Gross Domestic Product per capita;
expanded employment, but without an increase in unemployment rates, because immigrants had created at least as many jobs as they had taken;
an increase in per capita income without a reduction in the average real wages of local employees;
migrants contributed more to public revenue than they had obtained from public outlays overall;
a positive impact in the long-term on the balance of payments as the capital investment induced by migration augmented domestic savings and led to increased output.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are expenses for medical and legal conferences currently tax deductible.
(2) Is the Government aware of any abuse of the

QUESTION.PARA: present tax arrangements regarding medical and legal conferences.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:-

PARA.TAB: (1) The cost of attending medical and legal conferences is tax deductible where the conference has a sufficient connection with the production of the taxpayer's assessable income and where the expenses are not of a capital or private nature.

(2) The Government is aware that a minority of taxpayers sometimes seek to abuse the tax system. Those taxpayers expose themselves to the risk of substantial penalties following audit of their tax affairs by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). The ATO's activities are specifically directed, through a combination of help and enforcement, to maximising compliance with the tax law.
